question: The energy released when \pu{1 L} of the E10 fuel is burnt is \pu{30680 kJ} and the energy released when \pu{1 L} of the E5 fuel is burnt is \pu{31170 kJ}. Taking the energy released from burning \pu{1 L} of E5 as \pu{100 %}, what is the percentage of the energy released from burning \pu{1 L} of E10 fuel?
llm_output:
The percentage is obtained by comparing the energy released from 1 L of E10 with that from 1 L of E5 (taken as 100 %):

\[
\text{Percentage}=\frac{E_{\text{E10}}}{E_{\text{E5}}}\times 100\%
   =\frac{30680\ \text{kJ}}{31170\ \text{kJ}}\times 100\%
\]

\[
\frac{30680}{31170}=0.98428\;\;(\text{to 5 s.f.})
\]

\[
\text{Percentage}=0.98428\times 100\% = 98.428\%
\]

Rounded to two decimal places:

\[
\boxed{98.43\%}
\]

question: The mass of one gold atom is \pu{3.27E-22 g} and the density of gold is \pu{19.3 g cm^{-3}}. What is the molar volume of gold in \pu{cm^{3} mol^{-1}}?
llm_output:
The molar volume \(V_{\mathrm{m}}\) is the volume occupied by one mole of a substance.  
It can be obtained from the volume of a single atom and Avogadro’s number \(N_{\!A}=6.022\times10^{23}\ \mathrm{mol^{-1}}\):

\[
V_{\mathrm{m}} = \left(\frac{m_{\text{atom}}}{\rho}\right) N_{\!A}
\]

where  

* \(m_{\text{atom}} = 3.27\times10^{-22}\ \text{g}\) (mass of one Au atom)  
* \(\rho = 19.3\ \text{g cm}^{-3}\) (density of gold)

---

**1. Volume of a single gold atom**

\[
V_{\text{atom}} = \frac{m_{\text{atom}}}{\rho}
               = \frac{3.27\times10^{-22}\ \text{g}}{19.3\ \text{g cm}^{-3}}
               = 1.69\times10^{-23}\ \text{cm}^{3}
\]

---

**2. Volume of one mole of gold**

\[
V_{\mathrm{m}} = V_{\text{atom}}\; N_{\!A}
               = (1.69\times10^{-23}\ \text{cm}^{3})\,(6.022\times10^{23}\ \text{mol}^{-1})
               \approx 10.2\ \text{cm}^{3}\text{ mol}^{-1}
\]

---

\[
\boxed{10.2}\ \text{cm}^{3}\text{ mol}^{-1}
\]

question: The standard enthalpy change of the reaction \ce{NaOH + HCl -> NaCl + H2O} is \pu{-56.7 kJ mol^{-1}}, the standard enthalpy change of the reaction \ce{SiO2 + 6HF -> H2SiF6 + 2H2O} is \pu{-100.3 kJ mol^{-1}} and the standard enthalpy change of the reaction \ce{NaOH + HF -> H2O + NaF} is \pu{-61.5 kJ mol^{-1}}. What is the standard enthalpy change of the reaction \ce{SiO2 + 6NaF + 6HCl -> H2SiF6 + 6NaCl + 2H2O} in \pu{kJ mol^{-1}}?
llm_output:
The target reaction can be obtained by combining the given reactions as follows  

\[
\begin{aligned}
&\text{(3) reversed and multiplied by 6:}& 6\;\ce{NaF}+6\;\ce{H2O}&\rightarrow 6\;\ce{NaOH}+6\;\ce{HF}\qquad \Delta H = 6(+61.5)=+369.0\ \text{kJ}\\[2mm]
&\text{(1) multiplied by 6:}& 6\;\ce{NaOH}+6\;\ce{HCl}&\rightarrow 6\;\ce{NaCl}+6\;\ce{H2O}\qquad \Delta H = 6(-56.7)=-340.2\ \text{kJ}\\[2mm]
&\text{(2) as given:}& \ce{SiO2}+6\;\ce{HF}&\rightarrow \ce{H2SiF6}+2\;\ce{H2O}\qquad \Delta H = -100.3\ \text{kJ}
\end{aligned}
\]

Adding the three equations cancels \(\ce{NaOH}\), \(\ce{HF}\) and six molecules of \(\ce{H2O}\), leaving  

\[
\ce{SiO2 + 6 NaF + 6 HCl -> H2SiF6 + 6 NaCl + 2 H2O}
\]

The overall standard enthalpy change is  

\[
\Delta H^\circ = (+369.0) + (-340.2) + (-100.3) = -71.5\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}.
\]

\[
\boxed{-71.5}\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

question: At \pu{25 deg C}, the partial pressure of \ce{CO2} gas in a \pu{250 cm^{3}} fizzy drink can is \pu{3 atm}. The Henry's law constant for \ce{CO2} is \pu{0.033 mol dm^{-3} atm^{-1}}. The can contains only \pu{1.09 g} of \ce{CO2} as a gas. What is the pressure in the can at \pu{25 deg C} in \pu{kPa}?
Lactic acid has an acid dissociation constant, $K_a$, of \pu{1.38E-4}. What is the pKa of lactic acid?
llm_output:
The pKa is defined as  

\[
\text{p}K_a = -\log_{10} K_a
\]

For lactic acid  

\[
K_a = 1.38 \times 10^{-4}
\]

\[
\begin{aligned}
\log_{10} K_a &= \log_{10}(1.38) + \log_{10}(10^{-4}) \\
&= 0.1399 - 4 \\
&= -3.8601
\end{aligned}
\]

Thus  

\[
\text{p}K_a = -(-3.8601) = 3.8601 \approx 3.86
\]

\[
\boxed{3.86}
\]

question: The molar volume of gold is \pu{10.2 cm^{3} mol^{-1}}. The gold atoms occupy 74 % of the volume of the cubic unit cell. What is the radius of the gold atom in \pu{\A}?
llm_output:
The molar volume gives the volume per atom  

\[
V_{\text{atom}}=\frac{V_{\text{m}}}{N_{\!A}}
               =\frac{10.2\;\text{cm}^{3}\,\text{mol}^{-1}}
                      {6.022\times10^{23}\;\text{mol}^{-1}}
               =1.69\times10^{-23}\;\text{cm}^{3}.
\]

In an FCC unit cell there are 4 atoms, so the cell volume is  

\[
V_{\text{cell}} = 4V_{\text{atom}} = 6.78\times10^{-23}\;\text{cm}^{3}.
\]

Only 74 % of this volume is occupied by the atomic spheres:

\[
V_{\text{atoms}} = 0.74\,V_{\text{cell}}
                 = 5.01\times10^{-23}\;\text{cm}^{3}.
\]

If each atom is a sphere of radius \(r\),

\[
4\left(\frac{4}{3}\pi r^{3}\right)=V_{\text{atoms}}
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
\frac{16}{3}\pi r^{3}=5.01\times10^{-23}\;\text{cm}^{3}.
\]

Hence  

\[
r^{3}= \frac{3\,V_{\text{atoms}}}{16\pi}
     =\frac{3(5.01\times10^{-23})}{16\pi}
     =2.99\times10^{-24}\;\text{cm}^{3},
\]

\[
r = (2.99\times10^{-24})^{1/3}=1.44\times10^{-8}\;\text{cm}
   = 1.44\;\text{Å}.
\]

\[
\boxed{1.44\ \text{Å}}
\]

question: \pu{286000 tonnes} of polylactic acid (PLA) are manufactured each year. What is the mass of NaOH, in tonnes, needed to completely degrade all the PLA manufactured in one year to sodium lactate, assume the PLA is pure and ignoring the contribution from any end groups?

There are \pu{7.1E6} virus particles per \pu{cm^{3}} in the test solution. Each virus particle has approximately 20 spike proteins on its surface. What is the concentration of spike proteins, [SP], in the test sample in \pu{mol dm^{-3}}?
llm_output:
The number of virus particles per cubic decimetre is  

\[
7.1\times10^{6}\;\text{cm}^{-3}\times\frac{10^{3}\;\text{cm}^{3}}{1\;\text{dm}^{3}}
=7.1\times10^{9}\;\text{particles dm}^{-3}.
\]

Each particle carries 20 spike proteins, so the spike‑protein count is  

\[
7.1\times10^{9}\times20 = 1.42\times10^{11}\;\text{proteins dm}^{-3}.
\]

Converting to moles using Avogadro’s number \(N_{\!A}=6.022\times10^{23}\;\text{mol}^{-1}\):

\[
[\text{SP}] = \frac{1.42\times10^{11}}{6.022\times10^{23}}
           = 2.4\times10^{-13}\;\text{mol dm}^{-3}.
\]

\[
\boxed{2.4\times10^{-13}}\ \text{mol dm}^{-3}
\]

question: The enthalpy change of vaporization of methane is \pu{8.2 kJ mol^{-1}} and the enthalpy change of vaporization of oxygen is \pu{6.8 kJ mol^{-1}}. A plastic was degraded, resulting in a sample of mass \pu{1.044 g}, and titrations were used to determine the composition of this sample. The sample was dissolved in \pu{100 cm^{3}} of water to make a stock solution. \pu{19.40 cm^{3}} of \pu{0.100 mol dm^{-3}} NaOH solution was needed to neutralize \pu{20.00 cm^{3}} of this stock solution. What is the amount of acid in the sample (in moles)?
llm_output:
The moles of NaOH used in the titration are  

\[
n_{\text{NaOH}} = C_{\text{NaOH}}V_{\text{NaOH}}
                 = (0.100\ \text{mol L}^{-1})(19.40\ \text{mL}\times10^{-3}\ \text{L mL}^{-1})
                 = 0.00194\ \text{mol}.
\]

Assuming a 1 : 1 neutralisation (monoprotic acid),

\[
n_{\text{acid (in 20.00 cm}^3\text{ of stock)}} = n_{\text{NaOH}} = 0.00194\ \text{mol}.
\]

The stock solution was prepared in \(100\ \text{cm}^3\) of water, so the total amount of acid in the whole stock (and thus in the original sample) is

\[
n_{\text{acid (total)}} = 0.00194\ \text{mol}\times\frac{100\ \text{cm}^3}{20.00\ \text{cm}^3}
                         = 0.00194\ \text{mol}\times5
                         = 0.00970\ \text{mol}.
\]

\boxed{9.70\times10^{-3}\ \text{mol}}
\]

question: A catalyst for the hydrogenation of levulinic acid is the octahedral complex of formula \ce{[RuH2(CO)(PPh3)3]}. This complex is named dihydridocarbonyltris(triphenylphosphine)ruthenium(Z), where Z is the oxidation state of ruthenium. What is the integer Z?
llm_output:
The complex is neutral.  
- Each hydride (H⁻) contributes –1 charge.  
- Carbonyl (CO) and triphenylphosphine (PPh₃) are neutral ligands.

Let \(Z\) be the oxidation state of Ru:

\[
Z + 2(-1) + 0 + 0 = 0 \;\Longrightarrow\; Z - 2 = 0 \;\Longrightarrow\; Z = +2
\]

\[
\boxed{+2}
\]

question: What is the bond enthalpy of the \ce{O=O} bond in \pu{kJ mol^{-1}}, given that the bond enthalpy of the \ce{H-H} bond is \pu{432 kJ mol^{-1}}, the average bond enthalpy of \ce{O-H} is \pu{460 kJ mol^{-1}}, and the enthalpy change for the reaction \ce{H2 + 0.5 O2 -> H2O} is \pu{-241 kJ} per mole of hydrogen gas?
llm_output:
The enthalpy change for a reaction can be expressed in terms of bond enthalpies as  

\[
\Delta H = \sum\text{(bonds broken)}-\sum\text{(bonds formed)} .
\]

For the reaction  

\[
\ce{H2 + \tfrac12 O2 -> H2O}
\]

the bonds involved are  

* **Broken:** one \(\ce{H–H}\) bond ( \(D_{\ce{H–H}} = 432\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}\) ) and half an \(\ce{O=O}\) bond ( \(\tfrac12 D_{\ce{O=O}}\) ).  
* **Formed:** two \(\ce{O–H}\) bonds in water ( each \(D_{\ce{O–H}} = 460\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}\) ), giving \(2\times460 = 920\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}\).

Thus  

\[
\Delta H = D_{\ce{H–H}} + \tfrac12 D_{\ce{O=O}} - 2D_{\ce{O–H}} .
\]

Insert the known values and the given reaction enthalpy \(\Delta H = -241\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}\):

\[
-241 = 432 + \tfrac12 D_{\ce{O=O}} - 920 .
\]

Solve for \(D_{\ce{O=O}}\):

\[
\begin{aligned}
-241 &= -488 + \tfrac12 D_{\ce{O=O}} \\
\tfrac12 D_{\ce{O=O}} &= -241 + 488 = 247 \\
D_{\ce{O=O}} &= 2 \times 247 = 494\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}.
\end{aligned}
\]

\[
\boxed{494}\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

question: A small snack bag typically weighs \pu{22 g}. The entire content of this bag was crushed and dissolved in distilled water, resulting in a solution. This solution was then adjusted to a volume of \pu{250 cm^{3}} in a volumetric flask. To reach the red-brown endpoint, \pu{8.20 cm^{3}} of the aqueous silver nitrate(V) solution was required. What is the mass of sodium chloride in a small snack bag in grams?

The enthalpy of combustion of ethanol is \pu{-1276 kJ mol^{-1}} and the enthalpy of combustion of an isomer of octane is \pu{-5144 kJ mol^{-1}}. Assume that \pu{1 L} of E10 fuel contains \pu{100 mL} of ethanol and \pu{900 mL} of octane isomers. The density of pure ethanol is \pu{0.789 g cm^{-3}} and the density of pure octane isomers is \pu{0.703 g cm^{-3}}. What is the energy, in \pu{kJ}, released when \pu{1 L} of the E10 fuel is burnt?
What is the oxidation number of carbon in the reactants of Sabatier reaction?
llm_output:
**Step‑by‑step determination**

1. Write the Sabatier reaction:  

\[
\mathrm{CO_2 + 4\,H_2 \;\longrightarrow\; CH_4 + 2\,H_2O}
\]

2. Identify the carbon‑containing reactant: it is carbon dioxide, \(\mathrm{CO_2}\).

3. Assign the usual oxidation number to oxygen: \(-2\).

4. Let the oxidation number of carbon be \(x\).  
   For the neutral molecule \(\mathrm{CO_2}\),

\[
x + 2(-2) = 0 \;\Longrightarrow\; x - 4 = 0 \;\Longrightarrow\; x = +4.
\]

Thus, the oxidation number of carbon in the reactants (i.e., in \(\mathrm{CO_2}\)) is \(+4\).

\[
\boxed{+4}
\]

question: The standard enthalpy change of formation at \pu{298 K} is \pu{-393.5 kJ mol^{-1}} for \ce{CO2}, \pu{-424.8 kJ mol^{-1}} for \ce{KOH}, \pu{-285.8 kJ mol^{-1}} for \ce{H2O} and \pu{-1151.2 kJ mol^{-1}} for \ce{K2CO3}. What is the standard enthalpy change for the reaction \ce{CO2 + 2KOH -> H2O + K2CO3} in \pu{kJ mol^{-1}}?
llm_output:
The standard enthalpy change for the reaction is obtained from the heats of formation of the reactants and products:

\[
\Delta H^\circ_{\text{rxn}} = \sum \Delta H_f^\circ(\text{products})-\sum \Delta H_f^\circ(\text{reactants})
\]

\[
\begin{aligned}
\sum \Delta H_f^\circ(\text{products}) &= \Delta H_f^\circ(\ce{H2O})+\Delta H_f^\circ(\ce{K2CO3}) \\
&= (-285.8)+(-1151.2)= -1437.0\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1} \\[4pt]
\sum \Delta H_f^\circ(\text{reactants}) &= \Delta H_f^\circ(\ce{CO2})+2\,\Delta H_f^\circ(\ce{KOH}) \\
&= (-393.5)+2(-424.8)= -1243.1\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\end{aligned}
\]

\[
\Delta H^\circ_{\text{rxn}} = -1437.0 - (-1243.1)= -193.9\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

\[
\boxed{-193.9}\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

question: The density of liquid hydrogen is \pu{0.071 g cm^{-3}}. Assume the enthalpy change for the reaction \ce{H2 + 0.5 O2 -> H2O} is \pu{-241 kJ} per mole of hydrogen gas. What is the energy released, in \pu{kJ}, when the gas formed from \pu{1 dm^{3}} of liquid hydrogen is combusted?
llm_output:
The volume of liquid hydrogen is  

\[
V = 1\ \text{dm}^{3}=1000\ \text{cm}^{3}
\]

With a density \(\rho = 0.071\ \text{g cm}^{-3}\),

\[
m = \rho V = 0.071\ \frac{\text{g}}{\text{cm}^{3}}\times 1000\ \text{cm}^{3}=71\ \text{g}
\]

Molar mass of \(\ce{H2}\)  

\[
M_{\ce{H2}} = 2.016\ \text{g mol}^{-1}
\]

Number of moles of hydrogen gas that can be obtained from the liquid:

\[
n = \frac{m}{M_{\ce{H2}}}= \frac{71\ \text{g}}{2.016\ \text{g mol}^{-1}} = 35.24\ \text{mol}
\]

The enthalpy change for the combustion reaction  

\[
\ce{H2 + \tfrac12 O2 -> H2O}
\]

is \(\Delta H = -241\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}\) (per mole of \(\ce{H2}\)).  
Hence the total energy released is

\[
q = n\,\Delta H = 35.24\ \text{mol}\times (-241\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1})
      = -8.5\times10^{3}\ \text{kJ}
\]

The magnitude of the energy released is therefore  

\[
\boxed{8.5\times10^{3}\ \text{kJ}}
\]

question: If ten tonnes of Ambrox (\ce{C16H28O}) are produced every year, what is the number of moles produced per year?

Assume all processes take place at \pu{298 K}. The enthalpy change of formation of \ce{CH4(g)} is \pu{-74.8 kJ mol^{-1}}, of \ce{CO2(g)} is \pu{-393.5 kJ mol^{-1}} and it is \pu{-285.8 kJ mol^{-1}} for \ce{H2O(l)}. What is the enthalpy change for the reaction \ce{CH4(g) + 2H2O(l) -> CO2(g) + 4H2(g)} in \pu{kJ mol^{-1}}?
llm_output:
The enthalpy change for the reaction is obtained from the standard enthalpies of formation:

\[
\Delta H_{\text{rxn}}^{\circ}= \sum \Delta H_f^{\circ}(\text{products})-\sum \Delta H_f^{\circ}(\text{reactants})
\]

\[
\begin{aligned}
\Delta H_{\text{rxn}}^{\circ}
&= \bigl[\Delta H_f^{\circ}(\ce{CO2(g)})+4\Delta H_f^{\circ}(\ce{H2(g)})\bigr] \\
&\qquad -\bigl[\Delta H_f^{\circ}(\ce{CH4(g)})+2\Delta H_f^{\circ}(\ce{H2O(l)})\bigr] \\
&= \bigl[-393.5\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}+4(0)\bigr] -\bigl[-74.8\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}+2(-285.8\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1})\bigr] \\
&= -393.5\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1} - (-646.4\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}) \\
&= +252.9\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\end{aligned}
\]

\[
\boxed{+2.53\times10^{2}\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}}
\]

question: The concentration of \ce{CO2} in a \pu{250 cm^{3}} can of fizzy drink was found to be \pu{0.099 mol dm^{-3}}. What is, in grams, the mass of \ce{CO2} dissolved in a \pu{250 cm^{3}} can of fizzy drink?
llm_output:
The volume of the drink is  

\[
V = 250\ \text{cm}^{3}=250\ \text{mL}=0.250\ \text{dm}^{3}
\]

The concentration of dissolved \(\ce{CO2}\) is  

\[
c = 0.099\ \text{mol dm}^{-3}

      = 0.02475\ \text{mol}
\]

\[
M_{\ce{CO2}} = 12.01 + 2(16.00) = 44.01\ \text{g mol}^{-1}
\]

Mass of \(\ce{CO2}\) dissolved:

\[
m = nM = (0.02475\ \text{mol})(44.01\ \text{g mol}^{-1})
    = 1.09\ \text{g}

\[
\boxed{1.09\ \text{g}}
\]

question: The average bond enthalpy of \ce{C-C} is \pu{347 kJ mol^{-1}}, \ce{C-H} is \pu{413 kJ mol^{-1}}, \ce{O=O} is \pu{498 kJ mol^{-1}}, \ce{C-O} is \pu{358 kJ mol^{-1}}, \ce{C=O} is \pu{805 kJ mol^{-1}} and \ce{O-H} is \pu{464 kJ mol^{-1}}. What is the enthalpy of combustion of an isomer of octane in \pu{kJ mol^{-1}}?
llm_output:
The combustion of any C₈H₁₈ isomer is  

\[
\ce{C8H18 + \frac{25}{2} O2 -> 8 CO2 + 9 H2O}
\]

---

### 1.  Count the bonds that are broken  

* In an alkane C₈H₁₈  
  * C–C single bonds: \(8-1 = 7\)  
  * C–H bonds: 18  

* In the oxygen reactant  
  * O=O bonds: \(\dfrac{25}{2}=12.5\)

\[
\begin{aligned}
\text{Energy to break C–C} &= 7(347)=2429\;\text{kJ}\\
\text{Energy to break C–H} &= 18(413)=7434\;\text{kJ}\\
\text{Energy to break O=O} &= 12.5(498)=6225\;\text{kJ}\\[2mm]
\text{Total broken} &= 2429+7434+6225 = 16088\;\text{kJ}
\end{aligned}
\]

---

### 2.  Count the bonds that are formed  

* In 8 CO₂ each molecule has two C=O double bonds → \(8\times2 = 16\) C=O bonds.  
* In 9 H₂O each molecule has two O–H bonds → \(9\times2 = 18\) O–H bonds.

\[
\begin{aligned}
\text{Energy to form C=O} &= 16(805)=12880\;\text{kJ}\\
\text{Energy to form O–H} &= 18(464)=8352\;\text{kJ}\\[2mm]
\text{Total formed} &= 12880+8352 = 21232\;\text{kJ}
\end{aligned}
\]

---

### 3.  Enthalpy of combustion  

\[
\Delta H_{\text{comb}} \approx \sum\text{(bonds broken)}-\sum\text{(bonds formed)}
=16088\;\text{kJ}-21232\;\text{kJ}
= -5144\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

\[
\boxed{-5.14\times10^{3}}\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

question: In the reaction \ce{CO + H2O <=> CO2 + H2}, an initial mixture of \pu{40 mol} of \ce{CO}, \pu{20 mol} of \ce{H2}, and \pu{20 mol} of \ce{CO2} in contact with \pu{40 mol} of steam was allowed to come to equilibrium in a reactor at \pu{1100 K}. At \pu{1100 K} this reaction has a $K_p$ of 0.64. What is the number of moles of \ce{CO} leaving the reactor after equilibration?
llm_output:
The reaction  

\[
\ce{CO + H2O <=> CO2 + H2}
\]

has the equilibrium constant  

\[
K_{p}=0.64=\frac{P_{\ce{CO2}}P_{\ce{H2}}}{P_{\ce{CO}}P_{\ce{H2O}}}
\]

For an ideal‑gas mixture the partial pressures are proportional to mole fractions, so  

\[
K_{p}= \frac{y_{\ce{CO2}}\,y_{\ce{H2}}}{y_{\ce{CO}}\,y_{\ce{H2O}}}
      =\frac{n_{\ce{CO2}}\,n_{\ce{H2}}}{n_{\ce{CO}}\,n_{\ce{H2O}}}
\]

Let \(x\ be the extent of the forward reaction (mol of \(\ce{CO}\) that reacts).  

\[
\begin{aligned}
n_{\ce{CO}}   &= 40 - x\\
n_{\ce{H2O}}  &= 40 - x\\
n_{\ce{CO2}}  &= 20 + x\\
n_{\ce{H2}}   &= 20 + x
\end{aligned}
\]

Substituting into the expression for \(K_{p}\):

\[
0.64 = \frac{(20+x)^2}{(40-x)^2}
\]

Taking square root:

\[
\sqrt{0.64}=0.8 = \frac{20+x}{40-x}
\]

Solve for \(x\):

\[
20 + x = 0.8(40 - x) \\
20 + x = 32 - 0.8x \\
1.8x = 12 \\
x = \frac{12}{1.8}=.67\ \text{mol}
\]

Thus, \(6.67\ \text{mol}\) of \(\ce{CO}\) react (i.e., leave the reactor) to reach equilibrium.

\[
\boxed{6.67\ \text{mol}}
\]

question: The enthalpy change of formation of \ce{H2O(l)} is \pu{-285.8 kJ mol^{-1}}. What is the enthalpy change for the overall cell reaction during electrolysis of water, \ce{2H2O(l) -> 2H2(g) + O2(g)} in \pu{kJ mol^{-1}}?
llm_output:
The enthalpy change for the electrolysis reaction  

\[
\ce{2H2O(l) -> 2H2(g) + O2(g)}
\]

is obtained from the standard enthalpies of formation:

\[
\Delta H_{\text{rxn}} = \sum n\,\Delta H_f^\circ(\text{products})-\sum n\,\Delta H_f^\circ(\text{reactants})
\]

\[
\Delta H_{\text{rxn}} = [2(0)+1(0)] - [2(-285.8\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1})]
= 0 - (-571.6\ \text{kJ})
= +571.6\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

\[
\boxed{+571.6\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}}
\]

question: EDTA reacts with copper ions according to the equation \ce{Cu^{2+} + EDTA4_{(aq)} -> [CuEDTA]^{2-}_{(aq)}}. The end-point of the titration was determined using an indicator called murexide, and it was found that \pu{0.1 g} of X required \pu{21.70 cm^{3}} of \pu{0.02 mol dm^{-3}} EDTA solution for complete reaction. What is the percent by mass of copper in compound X?
llm_output:
The reaction between copper(II) ions and EDTA is 1 : 1:

\[
\ce{Cu^{2+} + EDTA^{4-} -> [CuEDTA]^{2-}}
\]

Hence the moles of Cu\(^{2+}\) present in the sample equal the moles of EDTA used.

**Moles of EDTA used**

\[
\begin{aligned}
V_{\text{EDTA}} &= 21.70\ \text{cm}^{3}=0.02170\ \text{L}\\[2pt]
c_{\text{EDTA}} &= 0.02\ \text{mol L}^{-1}\\[2pt]
n_{\text{EDTA}} &= c_{\text{EDTA}}\times V_{\text{EDTA}}\\
               &= 0.02\ \frac{\text{mol}}{\text{L}}\times 0.02170\ \text{L}\\
               &= 4.34\times10^{-4}\ \text{mol}
\end{aligned}
\]

Thus  

\[
n_{\text{Cu}^{2+}} = 4.34\times10^{-4}\ \text{mol}
\]

**Mass of copper in the sample**

\[
m_{\text{Cu}} = n_{\text{Cu}^{2+}}\times M_{\text{Cu}}
               = 4.34\times10^{-4}\ \text{mol}\times 63.55\ \frac{\text{g}}{\text{mol}}
               = 2.76\times10^{-2}\ \text{g}
\]

**Percent by mass of copper in X**

\[
\%\,\text{Cu} = \frac{m_{\text{Cu}}}{m_{\text{X}}}\times 100
              = \frac{2.76\times10^{-2}\ \text{g}}{0.100\ \text{g}}\times 100
              = 27.6\%
\]

\[
\boxed{27.6\%}
\]

question: A standard small bag typically contains \pu{22 g} of a snack. When a \pu{2.0 g} sample of the snack is completely burned, it results in a temperature rise of \pu{20.9 deg C} in \pu{500 g} of water within the calorimeter. The specific heat capacity of water is \pu{4.18 J K^{-1} g^{-1}}, and the conversion factor from kilojoules (kJ) to dietary calories is 0.239. What is the dietary calories content in a standard small bag of the snack?
llm_output:
The heat released by the burned sample is  

\[
q = m_{\text{water}}c_{\text{water}}\Delta T
    = (500\;\text{g})(4.18\;\text{J g}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1})(20.9\;\text{K})
    = 4.37\times10^{4}\;\text{J}=43.7\;\text{kJ}
\]

This corresponds to dietary calories (kilocalories) using the conversion \(1\;\text{kJ}=0.239\;\text{kcal}\):

\[
\text{kcal}_{\;2.0\text{ g}} = 43.7\;\text{kJ}\times0.239\;\frac{\text{kcal}}{\text{kJ}}
                              \approx 10.4\;\text{kcal}
\]

Thus the energy per gram of snack is  

\[
\frac{10.4\;\text{kcal}}{2.0\;\text{g}} = 5.2\;\text{kcal g}^{-1}
\]

A standard small bag contains \(22\;\text{g}\), so its dietary‑calorie content is  

\[
\boxed{115\ \text{kcal}}
\]

question: The density of liquid hydrogen is \pu{0.071 g cm^{-3}}. What is the number of moles of hydrogen molecules in \pu{1 dm^{3}} of liquid hydrogen?
llm_output:
The mass of liquid hydrogen in \(1\ \text{dm}^{3}\) is  

\[
m = \rho V = 0.071\ \frac{\text{g}}{\text{cm}^{3}}\times 1000\ \text{cm}^{3}=71\ \text{g}.
\]

The molar mass of \(\mathrm{H_2}\) is \(M = 2.016\ \text{g mol}^{-1}\).  
Hence the number of moles is  

\[
n = \frac{m}{M}= \frac{71\ \text{g}}{2.016\ \text{g mol}^{-1}}
   \approx 35.2\ \text{mol}.
\]

\[
\boxed{35.2}\ \text{mol}
\]

question: The enthalpy of combustion of ethanol is \pu{-1276 kJ mol^{-1}} and the enthalpy of combustion of an isomer of octane is \pu{-5144 kJ mol^{-1}}. Assume that \pu{1 L} of E5 fuel contains \pu{50 mL} of ethanol and \pu{950 mL} of octane isomers. The density of pure ethanol is \pu{0.789 g cm^{-3}} and the density of pure octane isomers is \pu{0.703 g cm^{-3}}. What is the energy, in \pu{kJ}, released when \pu{1 L} of the E5 fuel is burnt?

The reaction for the explosion of TNT is \ce{C7H5N3O6 -> 3CO + 3C + CO2 + 1.5H2 + 1.5N2 + H2O}. What the mass (in \pu{g}) of TNT that will explode to produce \pu{1.0 dm^{3}} of gas at room temperature and pressure, assuming that the molar volume of any gas is \pu{24 dm^{3}} at RTP?
llm_output:
The balanced decomposition of TNT is  

\[
\ce{C7H5N3O6 -> 3CO + 3C + CO2 + 1.5H2 + 1.5N2 + H2O}
\]

Only the gaseous products contribute to the gas volume.  
At room temperature and pressure (RTP) the gases are  

\[
\begin{aligned}
&3\ \text{mol CO} \\
&1\ \text{mol CO}_2 \\
&1.5\ \text{mol H}_2 \\
&1.5\ \text{mol N}_2 \\
&1\ \text{mol H}_2\text{O (vapour)}
\end{aligned}
\]

Hence, **1 mol of TNT produces**

\[
3+1+1.5+1.5+1 = 8\ \text{mol of gas}.
\]

---

### 1. Moles of gas required

The molar volume at RTP is \(V_{\text{m}} = 24\ \text{dm}^{3}\,\text{mol}^{-1}\).

\[
n_{\text{gas}} = \frac{V}{V_{\text{m}}}= \frac{1.0\ \text{dm}^{3}}{24\ \text{dm}^{3}\,\text{mol}^{-1}}
               = 4.1667\times10^{-2}\ \text{mol}.
\]

### 2. Moles of TNT needed

\[
n_{\text{TNT}} = \frac{n_{\text{gas}}}{8}
               = \frac{4.1667\times10^{-2}}{8}
               = 5.2083\times10^{-3}\ \text{mol}.
\]

### 3. Mass of TNT

Molar mass of TNT (\(\ce{C7H5N3O6}\)):

\[
M_{\text{TNT}} = 7(12.011) + 5(1.008) + 3(14.007) + 6(15.999)
               \approx 227.13\ \text{g mol}^{-1}.
\]

\[
m_{\text{TNT}} = n_{\text{TNT}}\times M_{\text{TNT}}
               = 5.2083\times10^{-3}\ \text{mol}\times 227.13\ \text{g mol}^{-1}
               \approx 1.18\ \text{g}.
\]

\[
\boxed{1.18\ \text{g}}
\]

question: What is the average molar mass of polymer chains in a polylactic acid (PLA) sample, measured in grams per mole, based on the dissolution of \pu{0.1619 g} of PLA in \pu{25 cm^{3}} of benzyl alcohol and titration with a \pu{0.04 mol dm^{-3}} \ce{KOH} solution, yielding a titre of \pu{6.81 cm^{3}}?
What is the oxidation state of phosphorus in phosphoric acid?
llm_output:
In phosphoric acid \(\mathrm{H_3PO_4}\) the oxidation numbers of the other atoms are known:

* Hydrogen is almost always \(+1\) when bonded to non‑metals.  
* Oxygen is almost always \(-2\) (except in peroxides, etc.).

Let the oxidation state of phosphorus be \(x\).  
The sum of the oxidation states in a neutral molecule must be zero:

\[
3(+1) + x + 4(-2) = 0
\]

\[
3 + x - 8 = 0 \quad\Longrightarrow\quad x = +5
\]

\[
\boxed{+5}
\]

question: What is the oxidation number of carbon in the products of Sabatier reaction?
llm_output:
The Sabatier reaction is  

\[
\mathrm{CO_2 + 4\,H_2 \;\longrightarrow\; CH_4 + 2\,H_2O}
\]

In the product methane, \(\mathrm{CH_4}\), hydrogen has an oxidation state of \(+1\).  
Since the molecule is neutral:

\[
\text{Oxidation state of C} + 4(+1) = 0 \;\Longrightarrow\; \text{Oxidation state of C} = -4
\]

Thus, the oxidation number of carbon in the product of the Sabatier reaction is  

\[
\boxed{-4}
\]

question: What is the oxidation number of hydrogen in the products of Sabatier reaction?
llm_output:
The Sabatier reaction produces methane and water:

\[
\mathrm{CO_2 + 4\,H_2 \;\longrightarrow\; CH_4 + 2\,H_2O}
\]

In both products, hydrogen is bonded to a more electronegative element (carbon in CH₄ and oxygen in H₂O). Therefore, hydrogen carries the usual oxidation state of **+1**.

\[
\boxed{+1}
\]

question: Assuming a bubble appearing during fermentation in cheese with diameter \pu{1.5 cm} at \pu{21 deg C} is pure \ce{CO2} at atmospheric pressure, p = \pu{101325 Pa}, what is the mass, in grams, of lactic acid which was fermented by the bacteria to produce this bubble?
llm_output:
The volume of a spherical bubble of diameter \(d = 1.5\;\text{cm}\) is  

\[
V = \frac{4}{3}\pi\left(\frac{d}{2}\right)^{3}
   = \frac{4}{3}\pi\,(0.75\;\text{cm})^{3}
   = \frac{4}{3}\pi\,(0.75\times10^{-2}\;\text{m})^{3}
   \approx 1.77\times10^{-6}\;\text{m}^{3}.
\]

At \(T = 21^{\circ}\text{C}=294\;\text{K}\) and atmospheric pressure \(p = 1.01325\times10^{5}\;\text{Pa}\), the amount of \(\ce{CO2}\) in the bubble (ideal‑gas law) is  

\[
n_{\ce{CO2}} = \frac{pV}{RT}
   = \frac{(1.01325\times10^{5}\;\text{Pa})(1.77\times10^{-6}\;\text{m}^{3})}
          {(8.314\;\text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1})(294\;\text{K})}
   \approx 7.3\times10^{-5}\;\text{mol}.
\]

Hetero‑fermentative lactic‑acid bacteria convert one mole of glucose to one mole of lactic acid and one mole of \(\ce{CO2}\) (e.g., \(\ce{C6H12O6 -> CH3CH(OH)COOH + C2H5OH + CO2}\)).  
Thus the moles of lactic acid produced equal the moles of \(\ce{CO2}\):

\[
n_{\text{lactic acid}} = n_{\ce{CO2}} \approx 7.3\times10^{-5}\;\text{mol}.
\]

The molar mass of lactic acid (\(\ce{C3H6O3}\)) is  

\[
M_{\text{lactic acid}} = 90.08\;\text{g mol}^{-1}.
\]

Hence the mass of lactic acid fermented is  

\[
m = n_{\text{lactic acid}}\,M_{\text{lactic acid}}
   \approx (7.3\times10^{-5}\;\text{mol})(90.08\;\text{g mol}^{-1})
   \approx 6.6\times10^{-3}\;\text{g}.
\]

\[
\boxed{6.6\times10^{-3}\ \text{g}}
\]

question:
This question is about benzene and its isomers

Working out the structure of benzene, $\mathrm{C}_{6} \mathrm{H}_{6}$, was one of the great achievements of $19^{\text {th }}$ century chemists. The carcinogenic hydrocarbon was first discovered by Michael Faraday at the Royal Institution in 1825 during the repeated fractional distillation of some oil residues.

Faraday analysed the pure benzene by passing its vapour over heated copper(II) oxide to produce carbon dioxide, water and copper. He collected and measured the volume of liquid water and gaseous $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ produced from a given mass of benzene.

Calculate the maximum mass of water that could be formed from $0.644 \mathrm{mmol}$ of benzene using Faraday's method.
llm_output:
The combustion of benzene over heated CuO can be written as  

\[
\mathrm{C_6H_6 + 7.5\,O_2 \longrightarrow 6\,CO_2 + 3\,H_2O}
\]

Thus **1 mol of benzene produces 3 mol of water**.

---

### 1.  Moles of water formed  

\[
n_{\text{H}_2\text{O}} = 3 \times n_{\text{C}_6\text{H}_6}
                     = 3 \times 0.644\;\text{mmol}
                     = 1.932\;\text{mmol}
\]

Convert to moles:

\[
1.932\;\text{mmol}=1.932\times10^{-3}\;\text{mol}
\]

---

### 2.  Mass of water  

Molar mass of water: \(M_{\text{H}_2\text{O}} = 18.015\;\text{g mol}^{-1}\).

\[
m_{\text{H}_2\text{O}} = n_{\text{H}_2\text{O}}\;M_{\text{H}_2\text{O}}
                       = (1.932\times10^{-3}\;\text{mol})(18.015\;\text{g mol}^{-1})
                       = 0.0348\;\text{g}
\]

---

\[
\boxed{0.0348}\ \text{g}
\]

question: The density of pure water is \pu{1 g cm^{-3}}, the melting point of pure water is \pu{273 K} and the standard enthalpy change of melting for pure water is \pu{6.01 kJ mol^{-1}}. The depression in freezing point can be calculated by $ rac{nRT_\mathrm{melt}^2}{\Delta H_\mathrm{melt}}$, where $n$ is the amount of substance (in \pu{mol}) of ions, $R$ is the gas constant, $T_\mathrm{melt}$ is the melting point of pure water, and $\Delta H_\mathrm{melt}$ is the standard enthalpy change of melting for pure water. What is the freezing point of a \pu{3 mol dm^{-3}} solution of sodium chloride in \pu{K}?
llm_output:
The freezing‑point depression for an electrolyte solution is  

\[
\Delta T_{\text{f}}=\frac{nRT_{\text{melt}}^{2}}{\Delta H_{\text{melt}}}
\]

where  

* \(n\) = total moles of ions per mole of water,  
* \(R = 8.314\;\text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1}\),  
* \(T_{\text{melt}} = 273\;\text{K}\),  
* \(\Delta H_{\text{melt}} = 6.01\times10^{3}\;\text{J mol}^{-1}\).

---

### 1.  Determine \(n\)

For a \(3\;\text{mol dm}^{-3}\) NaCl solution (density ≈ 1 g cm\(^{-3}\)):

* Mass of 1 L solution ≈ 1000 g → 1 kg water.  
* Moles of water in 1 kg: \(\displaystyle \frac{1000\;\text{g}}{18.015\;\text{g mol}^{-1}} = 55.5\;\text{mol}\).

Moles of NaCl per litre = 3 mol → moles of ions = \(2\times3 = 6\) mol (Na\(^+\) + Cl\(^-\)).

\[
n = \frac{\text{moles of ions}}{\text{moles of water}}
    = \frac{6}{55.5}=0.108\;\text{mol ion mol}^{-1}\text{ water}
\]

---

### 2.  Compute \(\Delta T_{\text{f}}\)

\[
\Delta T_{\text{f}}=
\frac{(0.108)(8.314\;\text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1})(273\;\text{K})^{2}}
     {6.01\times10^{3}\;\text{J mol}^{-1}}
\]

\[
(273\;\text{K})^{2}=7.4529\times10^{4}\;\text{K}^{2}
\]

\[
\Delta T_{\text{f}}=
\frac{0.108 \times 8.314 \times 7.4529\times10^{4}}
     {6.01\times10^{3}}
\approx \frac{6.69\times10^{4}}{6.01\times10^{3}}
\approx 11.2\;\text{K}
\]

---

### 3.  Freezing point of the solution

\[
T_{\text{freeze}} = T_{\text{melt}} - \Delta T_{\text{f}}
                  = 273\;\text{K} - 11.2\;\text{K}
                  \approx 261.8\;\text{K}
\]

Rounded to the appropriate number of significant figures:

\[
\boxed{262\ \text{K}}
\]

question: When fuel gases are supplied under the same pressure, the heat released per second in a burner is directly proportional to standard enthalpy change of combustion and inversely proportional to the square root of relative molecular mass. Assume hydrogen and methane are supplied under the same pressure. The heat released with \ce{H2} is \pu{-285.8 kJ mol^{-1}} and the heat released with \ce{CH4} is \pu{-890.3 kJ mol^{-1}}. What is the ratio of heat released per second in a burner fuelled by hydrogen compared to in the same burner fuelled by methane?

In the reaction \ce{CO + H2O <=> CO2 + H2}, an initial mixture of \pu{40 mol} of \ce{CO}, \pu{20 mol} of \ce{H2}, and \pu{20 mol} of \ce{CO2} in contact with \pu{40 mol} of steam was allowed to come to equilibrium in a reactor at \pu{1100 K}. At \pu{1100 K} this reaction has a $K_p$ of 0.64. What is the number of moles of \ce{CO2} leaving the reactor after equilibration?
llm_output:
The reaction  

\[
\ce{CO + H2O <=> CO2 + H2}
\]

has an initial composition  

\[
n_{\ce{CO}}^0 = 40\;\text{mol},\qquad 
n_{\ce{H2O}}^0 = 40\;\text{mol},\qquad 
n_{\ce{CO2}}^0 = 20\;\text{mol},\qquad 
n_{\ce{H2}}^0 = 20\;\text{mol}.
\]

Let \(\xi\) be the extent of the forward reaction (mol). At equilibrium  

\[
\begin{aligned}
n_{\ce{CO}} &= 40-\xi,\\
n_{\ce{H2O}} &= 40-\xi,\\
n_{\ce{CO2}} &= 20+\xi,\\
n_{\ce{H2}} &= 20+\xi .
\end{aligned}
\]

The total number of moles remains constant:

\[
N = (40-\xi)+(40-\xi)+(20+\xi)+(20+\xi)=120\;\text{mol}.
\]

For an ideal‑gas mixture the equilibrium constant in terms of partial pressures is

\[
K_p = \frac{P_{\ce{CO2}}P_{\ce{H2}}}{P_{\ce{CO}}P_{\ce{H2O}}}
      =\frac{y_{\ce{CO2}}y_{\ce{H2}}}{y_{\ce{CO}}y_{\ce{H2O}}}
      =\frac{(20+\xi)(20+\xi)}{(40-\xi)(40-\xi)} .
\]

Given \(K_p = 0.64\),

\[
0.64 = \frac{(20+\xi)^2}{(40-\xi)^2}
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
\frac{20+\xi}{40-\xi}= \sqrt{0.64}=0.8 .
\]

Solve for \(\xi\):

\[
20+\xi = 0.8(40-\xi)=32-0.8\xi \\
1.8\xi = 12 \;\Longrightarrow\; \xi = \frac{12}{1.8}=6.67\;\text{mol}.
\]

The increase in the amount of \(\ce{CO2}\) (i.e., the moles of \(\ce{CO2}\) that leave the reactor as product) is exactly the extent \(\xi\).

\[
\boxed{6.67\ \text{mol}}
\]

question:
For sustainable energy, hydrogen appears to be the best energy carrier. The most efficient way of using hydrogen is generation of electrical energy in a fuel cell. However, storing hydrogen in large quantities is a challenge in fuel cell applications. Among the chemical hydrides considered as solid hydrogen storage materials, sodium borohydride $\left(\mathrm{NaBH}_{4}\right)$, being non-toxic, stable and environmentally benign, appears to be the most promising one. The hydrolysis of sodium borohydride that releases $\mathrm{H}_{2}$ gas is a slow reaction at ambient temperature and, therefore, needs to be catalyzed.

$$
\mathrm{NaBH}_{4}(\mathrm{aq})+2 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}(I)  \xrightarrow{catalyst} \mathrm{Na}^{+}(\mathrm{aq})+\mathrm{BO}_{2}^{-}(\mathrm{aq})+4 \mathrm{H}_{2}(g)
$$

Colloidal ruthenium(0) nanoclusters are the most active catalysts in this hydrolysis even at room temperature and lead to a complete $\mathrm{H}_{2}$ release from sodium borohydride. Kinetic studies show that the catalytic hydrolysis of $\mathrm{NaBH}_{4}$ is a first order reaction with respect to the catalyst, but a zero order with respect to the substrate. The rate of hydrogen production per mole of ruthenium is $92 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{H}_{2} \cdot(\mathrm{mol} \mathrm{Ru})^{-1} \cdot \min ^{-1}$ at $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$.Calculate the amount of ruthenium catalyst (in $\mathrm{mg}$ ) which must be added to $0.100 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$ of $\mathrm{NaBH}_{4}$ solution with a concentration of $1.0 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{dm}^{-3}$ to supply the hydrogen gas at a rate of $0.100 \mathrm{dm}^{3} \cdot \mathrm{min}^{-1}$ at $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and $1.0 \mathrm{~atm}$, that is required for a portable fuel cell.

${ }^{131}$I is a radioactive isotope of iodine ( $\mathrm{e}^{-}$emitter) used in nuclear medicine for analytical procedures to determine thyroid endocrine disorders by scintigraphy. The decay rate constant, $k$, of ${ }^{131} \mathrm{I}$ is $9.93 \times 10^{-7} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}$.

Knowing that a Geiger counter detects activities of the order of $10^{-4} \mu \mathrm{c}$, calculate the minimum amount of ${ }^{131}$ I (in grams) which could be detected by this counter.

1 Curie (c) is the amount of a radioisotope that produces $3.7 \times 10^{10}$ disintegrations $s^{1}$.
llm_output:
The Geiger counter can detect activities as low as  

\[
10^{-4}\,\mu\text{c}=10^{-4}\times10^{-6}\,\text{c}=10^{-10}\,\text{c}.
\]

Since  

\[
1\;\text{c}=3.7\times10^{10}\;\text{s}^{-1},
\]

the smallest detectable activity is  

\[
A_{\min}=10^{-10}\times3.7\times10^{10}\;\text{s}^{-1}=3.7\;\text{s}^{-1}.
\]

For a radioactive nuclide, \(A=\lambda N\) where \(\lambda\) is the decay constant and \(N\) the number of atoms.  
With \(\lambda =9.93\times10^{-7}\;\text{s}^{-1}\),

\[
N_{\min}= \frac{A_{\min}}{\lambda}= \frac{3.7}{9.93\times10^{-7}}
        \approx 3.73\times10^{6}\ \text{atoms}.
\]

The mass corresponding to this number of \({}^{131}\text{I}\) atoms is  

\[
m_{\min}= N_{\min}\,\frac{M}{N_A}
        = 3.73\times10^{6}\times\frac{131\ \text{g mol}^{-1}}{6.022\times10^{23}\ \text{mol}^{-1}}
        \approx 8.1\times10^{-16}\ \text{g}.
\]

\[
\boxed{8.1\times10^{-16}}\ \text{g}
\]

question:
Extraction of gold using sodium cyanide, a very poisonous chemical, causes environmental problems and gives rise to serious public concern about the use of this so called "cyanide process". Thiosulfate leaching of gold has been considered as an alternative. In this process, the main reagent is ammonium thiosulfate, $\left(\mathrm{NH}_{4}\right)_{2} \mathrm{~S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}$, which is relatively non-toxic. Although this process appears to be environmentally benign, the chemistry involved is very complex and needs to be studied thoroughly. The solution used for leaching gold contains $\mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}^{2-}, \mathrm{Cu}^{2+}, \mathrm{NH}_{3}$, and dissolved $\mathrm{O}_{2}$. The solution must have a $\mathrm{pH}$ greater than 8.5 to allow free ammonia to be present.

According to the proposed mechanism, a local voltaic micro-cell is formed on the surface of gold particles during the leaching process and operates as follows:

Anode:

$\mathrm{Au}(\mathrm{s})+2 \mathrm{NH}_{3}(\mathrm{aq}) \rightarrow\left[\mathrm{Au}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{+}(\mathrm{aq})+e^{-}$

$\left[\mathrm{Au}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{+}(a q)+2 \mathrm{~S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}^{2-}(a q) \rightarrow\left[\mathrm{Au}\left(\mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{3-}(a q)+2 \mathrm{NH}_{3}(a q)$

Cathode:

$\left[\mathrm{Cu}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{4}\right]^{2+}(a q)+e^{-} \rightarrow\left[\mathrm{Cu}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{+}(a q)+2 \mathrm{NH}_{3}(a q)$

$\left[\mathrm{Cu}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{+}(a q)+3 \mathrm{~S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}^{2-}(a q) \rightarrow\left[\mathrm{Cu}\left(\mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}\right)_{3}\right]^{5-}(a q)+2 \mathrm{NH}_{3}(a q)$

The formation constants, $K_{f}$, of $\left[\mathrm{Au}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{+}$and $\left[\mathrm{Au}\left(\mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{3-}$ complexes are $1.00 \cdot 10^{26}$ and $1.00 \cdot 10^{28}$, respectively. Consider a leaching solution in which the equilibrium concentrations of the species are as follows:

$\left[\mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}^{2 \cdot}\right]=0.100 ;\left[\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right]=0.100$ and the total concentration of gold $(\mathrm{I})$ species $=$ $5.50 \cdot 10^{-5} \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{dm}^{-3}$.Calculate the percentage of gold $(I)$ ion that exists in the form of thiosulfate complex.

Dissociating gas cycle

Dinitrogen tetroxide forms an equilibrium mixture with nitrogen dioxide:

$$
\mathrm{N}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{4}(g) \rightleftharpoons 2 \mathrm{NO}_{2}(g)
$$

1.00 mol of $\mathrm{N}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{4}$ was put into an empty vessel with a fixed volume of $24.44 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$. The equilibrium gas pressure at $298 \mathrm{~K}$ was found to be 1.190 bar. When heated to $348 \mathrm{~K}$, the gas pressure increased to its equilibrium value of 1.886 bar.Calculate $\Delta S^{0}$ of the reaction, assuming that they do not change significantly with temperature.
llm_output:
The equilibrium constant in terms of partial pressures is  

\[
K_{p}= \frac{p_{\mathrm{NO_2}}^{\,2}}{p_{\mathrm{N_2O_4}}}
\]

For the reaction  

\[
\mathrm{N_2O_4(g)}\rightleftharpoons 2\;\mathrm{NO_2(g)}
\]

let the extent of dissociation be \(\xi\).  
Initially \(n_{\mathrm{N_2O_4}}^{0}=1.00\;\text{mol}\). At equilibrium  

\[
n_{\mathrm{N_2O_4}} = 1-\xi,\qquad 
n_{\mathrm{NO_2}} = 2\xi,\qquad 
n_{\text{tot}} = 1+\xi .
\]

Using the ideal‑gas relation \(P V = nRT\) (with \(R=0.08314\;\text{L·bar·K}^{-1}\text{mol}^{-1}\)):

* At \(T_{1}=298\;\text{K}\), \(P_{1}=1.190\;\text{bar}\)

\[
n_{1}= \frac{P_{1}V}{RT_{1}} =\frac{1.190\times24.44}{0.08314\times298}=1.1745\;\text{mol}
\]
\[
\xi_{1}=n_{1}-1=0.1745\;\text{mol}
\]

\[
p_{\mathrm{N_2O_4},1}=0.7033\,P_{1}=0.838\;\text{bar},\qquad
p_{\mathrm{NO_2},1}=0.2973\,P_{1}=0.354\;\text{bar}
\]

\[
K_{p,1}= \frac{(0.354)^2}{0.838}=0.1495
\]

* At \(T_{2}=348\;\text{K}\), \(P_{2}=1.886\;\text{bar}\)

\[
n_{2}= \frac{P_{2}V}{RT_{2}} =\frac{1.886\times24.44}{0.08314\times348}=1.594\;\text{mol}
\]
\[
\xi_{2}=n_{2}-1=0.594\;\text{mol}
\]

\[
p_{\mathrm{N_2O_4},2}=0.2548\,P_{2}=0.481\;\text{bar},\qquad
p_{\mathrm{NO_2},2}=0.7452\,P_{2}=1.406\;\text{bar}
\]

\[
K_{p,2}= \frac{(1.406)^2}{0.481}=4.11
\]

---

### Van’t Hoff analysis  

\[
\ln K_{p}= -\frac{\Delta H^{\circ}}{RT}+ \frac{\Delta S^{\circ}}{R}
\]

Using the two temperatures:

\[
\begin{aligned}
\ln K_{p,1}&=-1.902, &\frac{1}{T_{1}}&=0.0033557\;\text{K}^{-1}\\
\ln K_{p,2}&= 1.414, &\frac{1}{T_{2}}&=0.0028736\;\text{K}^{-1}
\end{aligned}
\]

The slope of the line \(\ln K_{p}\) vs. \(1/T\) is  

\[
m=\frac{\ln K_{p,2}-\ln K_{p,1}}{1/T_{2}-1/T_{1}}
      =\frac{1.414-(-1.902)}{0.0028736-0.0033557}
      =-6.88\times10^{3}\;\text{K}
\]

Since \(m=-\Delta H^{\circ}/R\),

\[
\Delta H^{\circ}= -mR = 6.88\times10^{3}\times 8.314\; \text{J mol}^{-1}
                =5.72\times10^{4}\;\text{J mol}^{-1}=57.2\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

The intercept gives \(\Delta S^{\circ}\):

\[
\frac{\Delta S^{\circ}}{R}= \ln K_{p,1}+ \frac{\Delta H^{\circ}}{R}\frac{1}{T_{1}}
= -1.902 + 6879\times0.0033557 = 21.17
\]

\[
\Delta S^{\circ}= 21.17\,R = 21.17\times 8.314\;\text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1}
                = 1.76\times10^{2}\;\text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1}
                = 0.176\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1}
\]

\[
\boxed{0.176}\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1}
\]

question:
The second law of thermodynamics is a fundamental law of science. In this problem we consider the thermodynamics of an ideal gas, phase transitions and chemical equilibrium.

3.00 mol of $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ gas expands isothermically (in thermal contact with the surroundings; temperature $=15^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ ) against a fixed external pressure of 1.00 bar. The initial and final volumes of the gas are $10.0 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$ and $30.0 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$, respectively.

Estimate the temperature at which the reaction would have an equilibrium constant equal to 1. Ignore slight variations in the thermodynamic data with temperature.

The rechargeable lithium ion battery has been developed in Japan.

The standard electromotive force of the battery is $3.70 \mathrm{~V}$. Assume that the halfreaction at the cathode is

$$
\mathrm{CoO}_{2}+\mathrm{Li}^{+}+\mathrm{e}^{-} \rightarrow \mathrm{LiCoO}_{2}
$$

and the half-reaction at the anode is

$$
\mathrm{LiC}_{6} \rightarrow 6 \mathrm{C}+\mathrm{Li}^{+}+\mathrm{e}^{-} .
$$

The battery cell is constructed using $\mathrm{LiCoO}_{2}$ and graphite (C) as the electrode materials.Calculate the mass of the anode in the completely charged state if $10.00 \mathrm{~g}$ of $\mathrm{LiCoO}_{2}$ and $10.00 \mathrm{~g}$ of graphite (C) are present initially.

In quantum mechanics, the movement of $\pi$ electrons along a neutral chain of conjugated carbon atoms may be modeled using the 'particle in a box' method. The energy of the $\pi$ electrons is given by the following equation:

$$
E_{\mathrm{n}}=\frac{n^{2} h^{2}}{8 m L^{2}}
$$

where $n$ is the quantum number $(n=1,2,3, \ldots), h$ is Planck's constant, $m$ is the mass of electron, and $L$ is the length of the box which may be approximated by $L=(k+2) \times 1.40 \AA$ ( $k$ being the number of conjugated double bonds along the carbon chain in the molecule). A photon with the appropriate wavelength $\lambda$ may promote $a$ m electron from the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) to the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO). An approximate semi-empirical formula based on this model which relates the wavelength $\lambda$, to the number of double bonds $k$ and constant $B$ is as follows:

$$
\lambda(\mathrm{nm})=B \times \frac{(k+2)^{2}}{(2 k+1)}
$$Using this semi-empirical formula with $B=65.01 \mathrm{~nm}$ calculate the value of the wavelength $\lambda(\mathrm{nm})$ for octatetraene $\left(\mathrm{CH}_{2}=\mathrm{CH}-\mathrm{CH}=\mathrm{CH}-\mathrm{CH}=\mathrm{CH}-\mathrm{CH}=\mathrm{CH}_{2}\right)$.

Acid-base equilibria in water

A solution $(\mathbf{X}$ ) contains two weak monoprotic acids (those having one acidic proton); HA with the acid dissociation constant of $K_{H A}=1.74 \times 10^{-7}$, and $H B$ with the acid dissociation constant of $K_{H B}=1.34 \times 10^{-7}$. The solution $\mathbf{X}$ has a $\mathrm{pH}$ of 3.75.Titration of $100 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of solution $\mathbf{X}$ requires $100 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of $\mathrm{NaOH}$ solution $\left(c=0.220 \mathrm{~mol} \cdot \mathrm{dm}^{-}{ }^{3}\right)$ for completion. Calculate the initial (total) concentration $\left(\mathrm{mol} \cdot \mathrm{dm}^{-3}\right.$ ) of acid HA in the solution $\mathbf{X}$.

Use reasonable approximations where appropriate. $\left[K_{w}=1.00 \times 10^{-14}\right.$ at $\left.298 \mathrm{~K}\right]$
llm_output:
The total concentration of the two acids is obtained from the amount of NaOH needed for complete neutralisation  

\[
n_{\text{acid}} = n_{\text{NaOH}} = 0.100\;\text{L}\times 0.220\;\frac{\text{mol}}{\text{L}} = 2.20\times10^{-2}\;\text{mol}
\]

\[
C_{\text{total}} = \frac{n_{\text{acid}}}{0.100\;\text{L}} = 0.220\;\text{M}
\]

Let  

\[
C_{\mathrm{HA}} = x,\qquad C_{\mathrm{HB}} = 0.220-x
\]

For a weak monoprotic acid \( \mathrm{HA}\rightleftharpoons\mathrm{H}^{+}+\mathrm{A}^{-}\)  

\[
K_a = \frac{[\mathrm{H}^{+}][\mathrm{A}^{-}]}{[\mathrm{HA}]}
\]

Because the dissociation is small \((K_a\ll [\mathrm{H}^{+}])\), the concentrations of the undissociated acids are essentially the total concentrations, and the charge balance gives  

\[
[\mathrm{H}^{+}] \approx \frac{K_{a1}C_{\mathrm{HA}}+K_{a2}C_{\mathrm{HB}}}{[\mathrm{H}^{+}]}
\]

or  

\[
[\mathrm{H}^{+}]^{2}=K_{a1}C_{\mathrm{HA}}+K_{a2}C_{\mathrm{HB}} .
\]

The measured pH is 3.75, therefore  

\[
[\mathrm{H}^{+}] = 10^{-3.75}=1.78\times10^{-4}\;\text{M},
\qquad [\mathrm{H}^{+}]^{2}=3.17\times10^{-8}\;\text{M}^{2}.
\]

Insert the expressions for \(C_{\mathrm{HA}}\) and \(C_{\mathrm{HB}}\):

\[
K_{a1}x+K_{a2}(0.220-x)=3.17\times10^{-8}.
\]

With \(K_{a1}=1.74\times10^{-7}\) and \(K_{a2}=1.34\times10^{-7}\),

\[
(1.74\times10^{-7}-1.34\times10^{-7})x+1.34\times10^{-7}\times0.220 = 3.17\times10^{-8},
\]

\[
4.0\times10^{-8}x + 2.95\times10^{-8}=3.17\times10^{-8},
\]

\[
x = \frac{3.17\times10^{-8}-2.95\times10^{-8}}{4.0\times10^{-8}}
      = 5.55\times10^{-2}\;\text{M}.
\]

Hence the initial concentration of acid HA in solution X is  

\[
\boxed{5.55\times10^{-2}}\ \text{mol·dm}^{-3}.
\]

question:
Acid-base equilibria in water

A solution $(\mathbf{X}$ ) contains two weak monoprotic acids (those having one acidic proton); HA with the acid dissociation constant of $K_{H A}=1.74 \times 10^{-7}$, and $H B$ with the acid dissociation constant of $K_{H B}=1.34 \times 10^{-7}$. The solution $\mathbf{X}$ has a $\mathrm{pH}$ of 3.75.Titration of $100 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of solution $\mathbf{X}$ requires $100 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of $\mathrm{NaOH}$ solution $\left(c=0.220 \mathrm{~mol} \cdot \mathrm{dm}^{-}{ }^{3}\right)$ for completion. Calculate the initial (total) concentration $\left(\mathrm{mol} \cdot \mathrm{dm}^{-3}\right.$ ) of acid HB in the solution $\mathbf{X}$.

Use reasonable approximations where appropriate. $\left[K_{w}=1.00 \times 10^{-14}\right.$ at $\left.298 \mathrm{~K}\right]$
llm_output:
The total amount of acid present in the 100 cm³ sample is equal to the amount of NaOH required for neutralisation:

\[
n_{\text{NaOH}} = c_{\text{NaOH}}V_{\text{NaOH}}
               = (0.220\;\text{mol dm}^{-3})(0.100\;\text{dm}^{3})
               = 0.0220\;\text{mol}
\]

Hence the total concentration of the two acids is  

\[
C_{\text{HA}}+C_{\text{HB}}=\frac{0.0220\;\text{mol}}{0.100\;\text{dm}^{3}}=0.220\;\text{mol dm}^{-3}\tag{1}
\]

The measured pH gives  

\[
[\mathrm{H}^{+}] = 10^{-3.75}=1.78\times10^{-4}\;\text{mol dm}^{-3}\tag{2}
\]

For each weak acid (assuming \(x\ll C\))  

\[
K_a = \frac{[\mathrm{H}^{+}]\,x}{C-x}\;\approx\;\frac{[\mathrm{H}^{+}]\,x}{C}
\qquad\Longrightarrow\qquad
x \approx \frac{K_a\,C}{[\mathrm{H}^{+}]}
\]

Thus the concentrations of the  \(\mathrm{H}^{+}\) contributed by HA and HB are  

\[
x_{\text{HA}} \approx \frac{K_{\text{HA}}C_{\text{HA}}}{[\mathrm{H}^{+}]},
\qquad
x_{\text{HB}} \approx \frac{K_{\text{HB}}C_{\text{HB}}}{[\mathrm{H}^{+}]}
\]

and the total \([\mathrm{H}^{+}]\) equals the sum of these contributions:

\[
\frac{K_{\text{HA}}C_{\text{HA}}}{[\mathrm{H}^{+}]}
+\frac{K_{\text{HB}}C_{\text{HB}}}{[\mathrm{H}^{+}]}
= [\mathrm{H}^{+}]
\]

Multiplying by \([\mathrm{H}^{+}]\) gives  

\[
K_{\text{HA}}C_{\text{HA}}+K_{\text{HB}}C_{\text{HB}}=[\mathrm{H}^{+}]^{2}\tag{3}
\]

Insert the numerical data  

\[
(1.74\times10^{-7})C_{\text{HA}}+(1.34\times10^{-7})C_{\text{HB}}
=(1.78\times10^{-4})^{2}=3.17\times10^{-8}
\]

Together with (1) (\(C_{\text{HA}}=0.220-C_{\text{HB}}\)) we obtain  

\[
1.74\times10^{-7}(0.220-C_{\text{HB}})+1.34\times10^{-7}C_{\text{HB}}=3.17\times10^{-8}
\]

\[
\Rightarrow\; -4.0\times10^{-8}C_{\text{HB}} = -6.60\times10^{-9}
\]

\[
\boxed{C_{\text{HB}} = 0.165\;\text{mol dm}^{-3}}
\]

Thus the initial concentration of the weak acid \( \mathrm{HB} \) in solution X is  

\[
\boxed{0.165}\ \text{mol·dm}^{-3}
\]

question:
The second law of thermodynamics is a fundamental law of science. In this problem we consider the thermodynamics of an ideal gas, phase transitions and chemical equilibrium.

3.00 mol of $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ gas expands isothermically (in thermal contact with the surroundings; temperature $=15^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ ) against a fixed external pressure of 1.00 bar. The initial and final volumes of the gas are $10.0 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$ and $30.0 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$, respectively.

From the data given in the phase diagram, calculate the molar enthalpy change of sublimation of $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$. Write down the formula used.
llm_output:
The molar enthalpy change of sublimation can be obtained from the heat absorbed during the isothermal expansion of the gas.  
For an ideal gas undergoing a reversible isothermal expansion

\[
q_{\text{rev}} = -w_{\text{rev}} = nRT\ln\!\left(\frac{V_{2}}{V_{1}}\right)
\]

and, at constant temperature, the enthalpy change equals the heat transferred at constant pressure:

\[
\Delta H_{\text{sub}} = q_{\text{rev}} = nRT\ln\!\left(\frac{V_{2}}{V_{1}}\right)
\]

Hence the molar (per‑mole) enthalpy change is

\[
\boxed{\Delta H_{\text{sub,mol}} = RT\ln\!\left(\frac{V_{2}}{V_{1}}\right)}
\]

Substituting the data ( \(R = 8.314\;\text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1}\), \(T = 15^{\circ}\text{C}=288\;\text{K}\), \(V_{2}=30.0\;\text{dm}^{3}\), \(V_{1}=10.0\;\text{dm}^{3}\) ):

\[
\Delta H_{\text{sub,mol}} = (8.314\;\text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1})(288\;\text{K})\,
\ln\!\left(\frac{30.0}{10.0}\right)
= 2.63\times10^{3}\;\text{J mol}^{-1}
\]

\[
\boxed{2.63\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}}
\]

question:
Lactic acid is formed in the muscles during intense activity (anaerobic metabolism). In the blood, lactic acid is neutralized by reaction with hydrogen carbonate. This will be illustrated by the following calculations:

Lactic acid written as HL is monoprotic, and the acid dissociation constant is $K_{\mathrm{HL}}=1.4 \times 10^{-4}$.

The acid dissociation constants for carbonic acid are: $K_{\mathrm{a} 1}=4.5 \times 10^{-7}$ and $K_{\mathrm{a} 2}=$ $4.7 \times 10^{-11}$. All carbon dioxide remains dissolved during the reactions.

$\mathrm{pH}$ in the blood of a person changed from 7.40 to 7.00 due to lactic acid formed during physical activity. Let an aqueous solution having $\mathrm{pH}=7.40$ and $\left[\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right]=$ 0.022 represent blood in the following calculation. How many moles of lactic acid have been added to $1.00 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$ of this solution when its $\mathrm{pH}$ has become 7.00 ?
The standard deviation in measuring the diameter?d?of a sphere is plus or minus 0.02 centimeter. What is the standard deviation in the calculated volume?V?of the sphere if?\(d = 2.35\)?centimeters?
llm_output:
The volume of a sphere in terms of its diameter \(d\) is  

\[
V=\frac{4}{3}\pi\left(\frac{d}{2}\right)^{3}= \frac{\pi}{6}\,d^{3}.
\]

Using linear error propagation,

\[
\sigma_V =\left|\frac{dV}{dd}\right|\sigma_d,
\qquad 
\frac{dV}{dd}= \frac{\pi}{6}\cdot 3d^{2}= \frac{\pi}{2}d^{2}.
\]

Hence  

\[
\sigma_V =\frac{\pi}{2}d^{2}\,\sigma_d.
\]

Insert \(d = 2.35\ \text{cm}\) and \(\sigma_d = 0.02\ \text{cm}\):

\[
\begin{aligned}
d^{2} &= (2.35)^2 = 5.5225\ \text{cm}^2,\\[4pt]
\sigma_V &= \frac{\pi}{2}\times 5.5225 \times 0.02
          \approx 8.6747 \times 0.02
          \approx 0.173\ \text{cm}^3.
\end{aligned}
\]

Rounded to the appropriate precision,

\[
\boxed{0.17}\ \text{cm}^3.
\]

question:
When the fresh-water rivers that run into the Chesapeake Bay flood after heavy rains in the spring, the increase in fresh water in the Bay causes a decrease in the salinity in the areas where oysters grow. The minimum concentration of chloride ions needed in oyster beds for normal growth is $8 \mathrm{ppm}\left(8 \mathrm{mg} \mathrm{dm}^{-3}\right)$.

After one week of heavy rain, the following analysis is done on water from the bay. To a $50.00 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ sample of bay water a few drops of a $\mathrm{K}_{2} \mathrm{CrO}_{4}$ solution are added. The sample is then titrated with $16.16 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of a $0.00164 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{AgNO}_{3}$ solution. After $\mathrm{AgNO}_{3}$ solution has been added to the sample a bright red-orange precipitate forms.

The chloride concentration in another $50.00 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ sample of bay water was determined by the Volhard method. In this method an excess of $\mathrm{AgNO}_{3}$ is added to the sample. The excess $\mathrm{Ag}^{+}$is titrated with standardized $\mathrm{KSCN}$, forming a precipitate of $\mathrm{AgSCN}$. The endpoint is signalled by the formation of the reddish-brown $\mathrm{FeSCN}^{2+}$ complex that forms when $\mathrm{Ag}^{+}$is depleted. If the excess $\mathrm{Ag}^{+}$from the addition of $50.00 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of $0.00129 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{AgNO}_{3}$ to the water sample required $27.46 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of $1.4110^{-3}$ M KSCN for titration, calculate the concentration of chloride in the bay water sample.

In natural waters with much higher concentration of $\mathrm{Cl}^{-}$, the $\mathrm{Cl}^{-}$can be determined gravimetrically by precipitating the $\mathrm{Cl}^{-}$as $\mathrm{AgCl}$. A complicating feature of this method is the fact that $\mathrm{AgCl}$ is susceptible to photodecomposition as shown by the reaction:

$$
\mathrm{AgCl}(\mathrm{s}) \rightarrow \mathrm{Ag}(\mathrm{s})+1 / 2 \mathrm{Cl}_{2}(\mathrm{~g})
$$

Furthermore, if this photodecomposition occurs in the presence of excess $\mathrm{Ag}^{+}$, the following additional reaction occurs:

$3 \mathrm{Cl}_{2}(\mathrm{~g})+3 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}+5 \mathrm{Ag}^{+} \rightarrow 5 \mathrm{AgCl}+\mathrm{ClO}_{3}{ }^{-}+6 \mathrm{H}^{+}$

If $0.010 \mathrm{~g}$ of a $3.000 \mathrm{~g}$ sample of $\mathrm{AgCl}$ contaminated with excess $\mathrm{Ag}^{+}$undergoes photodecomposition by the above equations
llm_output:
The amount of AgCl that undergoes photodecomposition is  

\[
n_{\text{AgCl}}=\frac{0.010\;\text{g}}{M_{\text{AgCl}}}
               =\frac{0.010}{143.32}\;\text{mol}
               =6.98\times10^{-5}\;\text{mol}
\]

For each mole of AgCl that decomposes  

\[
\text{AgCl}\;(s)\;\longrightarrow\;\text{Ag}\;(s)+\tfrac12\text{Cl}_2(g)
\]

\(0.5\) mol Cl₂ is produced.  
The Cl₂ then reacts with excess Ag⁺ according to  

\[
3\text{Cl}_2+3\text{H}_2\text{O}+5\text{Ag}^+\;\longrightarrow\;5\text{AgCl}+ \text{ClO}_3^-+6\text{H}^+
\]

If \(x\) mol of AgCl decompose, the amount of Cl₂ formed is \(0.5x\) mol.  
Setting \(3y = 0.5x\) (all Cl₂ reacts) gives \(y = x/6\).  
Thus the second reaction produces  

\[
\text{ClO}_3^- :\; y = \frac{x}{6}
\]

Hence the moles of chlorate formed are  

\[
n_{\text{ClO}_3^-}= \frac{n_{\text{AgCl}}}{6}
                  =\frac{6.98\times10^{-5}}{6}
                  =1.16\times10^{-5}\;\text{mol}
\]

Assuming the sample is finally dissolved in a volume of \(1.00\;\text{dm}^3\), the concentration of the product is  

\[
c = \frac{n_{\text{ClO}_3^-}}{V}=1.16\times10^{-5}\;\text{mol dm}^{-3}
\]

Rounded to two significant figures (as dictated by the mass \(0.010\;\text{g}\)):

\[
\boxed{1.2\times10^{-5}}\ \text{mol dm}^{-3}
\]

question: Calculate the hydronium ion concentration in a solution that is \(2.0 \times 10^{-4}\,\text{M}\) in aniline hydrochloride, \(\text{C}_6\text{H}_5\text{NH}_3\text{Cl}\).

Acid-base equilibria in water

A solution $(\mathbf{X}$ ) contains two weak monoprotic acids (those having one acidic proton); HA with the acid dissociation constant of $K_{H A}=1.74 \times 10^{-7}$, and $H B$ with the acid dissociation constant of $K_{H B}=1.34 \times 10^{-7}$. The solution $\mathbf{X}$ has a $\mathrm{pH}$ of 3.75.Calculate the $\mathrm{pH}$ of the solution $\mathbf{Y}$ in which the concentration of $\mathrm{NaA}$ initially was $6.00 \times 10^{-2}$ $\mathrm{mol} \cdot \mathrm{dm}^{-3}$ and that of $\mathrm{NaB}$ $4.00 \times 10^{-2} \mathrm{~mol} \cdot \mathrm{dm}^{-3}$.
llm_output:
The salts NaA and NaB furnish the conjugate bases \(A^{-}\) and \(B^{-}\) in water:

\[
\begin{aligned}
A^{-}+H_{2}O &\rightleftharpoons HA + OH^{-}\qquad K_{bA}= \frac{K_w}{K_{HA}}\\[2mm]
B^{-}+H_{2}O &\rightleftharpoons HB + OH^{-}\qquad K_{bB}= \frac{K_w}{K_{HB}}
\end{aligned}
\]

with \(K_w = 1.0\times10^{-14}\).

\[
K_{bA}= \frac{1.0\times10^{-14}}{1.74\times10^{-7}} = 5.75\times10^{-8},
\qquad
K_{bB}= \frac{1.0\times10^{-14}}{1.34\times10^{-7}} = 7.46\times10^{-8}
\]

Let the total hydroxide concentration be \(y=[OH^-]\).  
For each base \(i\) (\(i=A,B\)) the mass‑balance and equilibrium give  

\[
[A_i^-]=\frac{C_i\,y}{K_{b i}+y},\qquad
[HA_i]=\frac{C_i K_{b i}}{K_{b i}+y}
\]

where \(C_A=0.0600\;{\rm M}\) and \(C_B=0.0400\;{\rm M}\).  
Since each hydrolysis produces one \(\mathrm{OH^-}\),

\[
y=[HA_A]+[HB_B]=\frac{C_A K_{bA}}{K_{bA}+y}+\frac{C_B K_{bB}}{K_{bB}+y}
\]

Because \(y\gg K_{bA},K_{bB}\) (the bases are very weak), we may set \(K_{b i}+y\approx y\):

\[
y\approx\frac{C_A K_{bA}+C_B K_{bB}}{y}
\;\Longrightarrow\;
y^{2}=C_A K_{bA}+C_B K_{bB}
\]

\[
y=\sqrt{(0.0600)(5.75\times10^{-8})+(0.0400)(7.46\times10^{-8})}
      =\sqrt{6.43\times10^{-9}}
      =8.0\times10^{-5}\;{\rm M}
\]

Thus  

\[
pOH=-\log_{10}(8.0\times10^{-5})=4.10
\qquad\Longrightarrow\qquad
pH=14-pOH=9.90
\]

\[
\boxed{9.90}
\]

question: What mass of $\ce{Cu(IO_3)_2}$ can be formed from 0.475 g of $\ce{CuSO_4??5H_2O}$?
Calculate the molar solubility of PbS in a solution in which $\ce{[H_3O^+]}$ is held constant at $3.0\times10^{-1}\ \text{M}$.
llm_output:
The dissolution equilibrium is  

\[
\ce{PbS(s) <=> Pb^{2+} + S^{2-}},\qquad K_{sp}= [\ce{Pb^{2+}}][\ce{S^{2-}}]
\]

In the acidic solution the sulfide ion is protonated:

\[
\begin{aligned}
\ce{HS^- &<=> S^{2-}+H^+}\qquad K_{2}= \frac{[\ce{HS^-}]}{[\ce{S^{2-}}][\ce{H^+}]}=\frac{1}{K_{a2}}\\[4pt]
\ce{H2S &<=> HS^-+H^+}\qquad K_{1}= \frac{[\ce{H2S}]}{[\ce{HS^-}][\ce{H^+}]}=\frac{1}{K_{a1}}
\end{aligned}
\]

Hence  

\[
[\ce{HS^-}] = \frac{[\ce{S^{2-}}][\ce{H^+}]}{K_{a2}},\qquad
[\ce{H2S}] = \frac{[\ce{S^{2-}}][\ce{H^+}]^{2}}{K_{a1}K_{a2}}
\]

If the molar solubility is \(s\) (so \([\ce{Pb^{2+}}]=s\)), the total dissolved sulfide is  

\[
s = [\ce{S^{2-}}] + [\ce{HS^-}] + [\ce{H2S}]
    = [\ce{S^{2-}}]\!\left(1+\frac{[\ce{H^+}]}{K_{a2}}+\frac{[\ce{H^+}]^{2}}{K_{a1}K_{a2}}\right)
\]

Define  

\[
D = 1+\frac{[\ce{H^+}]}{K_{a2}}+\frac{[\ce{H^+}]^{2}}{K_{a1}K_{a2}}
\]

Then \([\ce{S^{2-}}]=s/D\) and the solubility product gives  

\[
K_{sp}=s\frac{s}{D}= \frac{s^{2}}{D}\;\Longrightarrow\; s = \sqrt{K_{sp}\,D}
\]

Using the data  

\[
K_{sp}(\ce{PbS}) = 8.0\times10^{-28},\qquad
K_{a1}=1.0\times10^{-7},\qquad
K_{a2}=1.0\times10^{-14},\qquad
[\ce{H^+}]=3.0\times10^{-1}\ \text{M}
\]

\[
\begin{aligned}
D &= 1+\frac{0.30}{1.0\times10^{-14}}+\frac{(0.30)^{2}}{(1.0\times10^{-7})(1.0\times10^{-14})}\\
  &\approx 1 + 3.0\times10^{13}+9.0\times10^{19}\;\approx\;9.0\times10^{19}
\end{aligned}
\]

\[
s = \sqrt{(8.0\times10^{-28})(9.0\times10^{19})}
   = \sqrt{7.2\times10^{-8}}
   \approx 2.7\times10^{-4}\ \text{M}
\]

\[
\boxed{2.7\times10^{-4}}\ \text{M}
\]

question: What mass in grams of $\ce{CO_2}$ is evolved in the complete decomposition of a 2.300 - g sample that is 38.0% $\ce{MgCO_3}$ and 42.0% $\ce{K_2CO_3}$ by mass?
A 50.00 - mL portion of an HCl solution required 29.71 mL of 0.01963 M $\ce{Ba(OH)_2}$ to reach an end point with bromocresol green indicator. Calculate the molar concentration of the HCl.
Calculate the molar solubility of $\ce{ZnCO_3}$ in a solution buffered to a pH of 7.00.
llm_output:
The dissolution equilibrium of zinc carbonate is  

\[
\ce{ZnCO3(s) <=> Zn^{2+} + CO3^{2-}},\qquad K_{sp}= [\ce{Zn^{2+}}][\ce{CO3^{2-}}].
\]

Let the molar solubility be \(s\;(\text{M})\). Then  

\[
[\ce{Zn^{2+}}]=s .
\]

Because the solution is buffered at pH = 7.00, the carbonate ion is protonated according to the equilibria of carbonic acid:

\[
\begin{aligned}
\ce{H2CO3 &<=> H^{+} + HCO3^{-}} & K_{a1}=10^{-pK_{a1}}=10^{-6.35}=4.47\times10^{-7},\\[2mm]
\ce{HCO3^{-} &<=> H^{+} + CO3^{2-}} & K_{a2}=10^{-pK_{a2}}=10^{-10.33}=4.68\times10^{-11}.
\end{aligned}
\]

At pH = 7, \([\ce{H^{+}}]=10^{-7}\,\text{M}\). Hence  

\[
\frac{[\ce{HCO3^{-}}]}{[\ce{H2CO3}]}=\frac{K_{a1}}{[\ce{H^{+}}]}=
\frac{4.47\times10^{-7}}{10^{-7}}=4.47,
\]

\[
\frac{[\ce{CO3^{2-}}]}{[\ce{HCO3^{-}}]}=\frac{K_{a2}}{[\ce{H^{+}}]}=
\frac{4.68\times10^{-11}}{10^{-7}}=4.68\times10^{-4}.
\]

Let \([\ce{H2CO3}]=c\). Then  

\[
\begin{aligned}
[\ce{HCO3^{-}}]&=4.47c,\\
[\ce{CO3^{2-}}]&=4.68\times10^{-4}\,[\ce{HCO3^{-}}]=4.68\times10^{-4}\times4.47c
               =2.09\times10^{-3}c .
\end{aligned}
\]

The total dissolved carbonate (which equals the amount of solid that has dissolved) is  

\[
s=[\ce{H2CO3}]+[\ce{HCO3^{-}}]+[\ce{CO3^{2-}}]
  =c\bigl(1+4.47+2.09\times10^{-3}\bigr)
  =5.472\,c,
\]

so  

\[
c=\frac{s}{5.472},\qquad 
[\ce{CO3^{2-}}]=2.09\times10^{-3}\,c
               =\frac{2.09\times10^{-3}}{5.472}\,s
               =3.82\times10^{-4}\,s .
\]

Insert this expression for \([\ce{CO3^{2-}}]\) into the solubility‑product expression:

\[
K_{sp}=s\,[\ce{CO3^{2-}}]=s\,(3.82\times10^{-4}s)=3.82\times10^{-4}s^{2}.
\]

For zinc carbonate, \(K_{sp}=1.5\times10^{-10}\) (25 °C). Solving for \(s\),

\[
s^{2}= \frac{K_{sp}}{3.82\times10^{-4}}
      =\frac{1.5\times10^{-10}}{3.82\times10^{-4}}
      =3.93\times10^{-7},
\qquad
s=\sqrt{3.93\times10^{-7}}
  =6.3\times10^{-4}\;\text{M}.
\]

\[
\boxed{6.3\times10^{-4}}\ \text{M}
\]

question: Calculate the molar solubility of PbS in a solution in which $\ce{[H_3O^+]}$ is held constant at $3.0\times10^{-4}\ \text{M}$.
llm_output:
The dissolution equilibrium is  

\[
\ce{PbS(s) <=> Pb^{2+} + S^{2-}},\qquad K_{sp}=8.0\times10^{-28}
\]

In the acidic solution the sulfide ion is protonated:

\[
\begin{aligned}
\ce{S^{2-}+H^{+} &<=> HS^{-}} &K_{2}= \frac{[HS^-]}{[S^{2-}][H^+]} =\frac{1}{K_{a2}}
      =\frac{1}{10^{-19}} =10^{19}\\[4pt]
\ce{HS^{-}+H^{+} &<=> H2S} &K_{1}= \frac{[H_2S]}{[HS^-][H^+]} =\frac{1}{K_{a1}}
      =\frac{1}{10^{-7}} =10^{7}
\end{aligned}
\]

With \([H^+] = 3.0\times10^{-4}\,\text{M}\),

\[
\begin{aligned}
[HS^-] &= K_{2}[S^{2-}][H^+] =10^{19}(3.0\times10^{-4})[S^{2-}]
        =3.0\times10^{15}[S^{2-}],\\[4pt]
[H_2S] &= K_{1}[HS^-][H^+] =10^{7}(3.0\times10^{15}[S^{2-}])(3.0\times10^{-4})
        =9.0\times10^{18}[S^{2-}].
\end{aligned}
\]

The total dissolved sulfide concentration (which equals the molar solubility \(s\)) is  

\[
s=[S^{2-}]+[HS^-]+[H_2S]\approx 9.0\times10^{18}[S^{2-}]
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
[S^{2-}] =\frac{s}{9.0\times10^{18}} .
\]

Because each mole of dissolved PbS gives one \(\ce{Pb^{2+}}\),

\[
K_{sp}= [\ce{Pb^{2+}}][\ce{S^{2-}}]= s\left(\frac{s}{9.0\times10^{18}}\right)
      =\frac{s^{2}}{9.0\times10^{18}} .
\]

Hence  

\[
s^{2}=K_{sp}\,(9.0\times10^{18})
      =(8.0\times10^{-28})(9.0\times10^{18})
      =7.2\times10^{-9},
\]

\[
s =\sqrt{7.2\times10^{-9}}
   =8.5\times10^{-5}\;\text{M}.
\]

\[
\boxed{8.5\times10^{-5}}\ \text{M}
\]

question: A 0.4126 - g sample of primary - standard $\ce{Na_2CO_3}$ was treated with 40.00 mL of dilute perchloric acid. The solution was boiled to remove $\ce{CO_2}$, following which the excess $\ce{HClO_4}$ was back - titrated with 9.20 mL of dilute NaOH. In a separate experiment, it was established that 26.93 mL of the $\ce{HClO_4}$ neutralized the NaOH in a 25.00 - mL portion. Calculate the molarities of the NaOH.
llm_output:
The back‑titration gives the relationship between the unknown molarity of the NaOH solution \((M_{\text{NaOH}})\) and the molarity of the perchloric acid \((M_{\text{HClO}_4})\).

1. **Calibration of the acid**  

   \[
   M_{\text{NaOH}}\;(0.02500\ \text{L}) = M_{\text{HClO}_4}\;(0.02693\ \text{L})
   \]
   \[
   \Rightarrow\; M_{\text{HClO}_4}= \frac{M_{\text{NaOH}}\times0.02500}{0.02693}
   \tag{1}
   \]

2. **Moles of Na\(_2\)CO\(_3\) in the sample**  

   \[
   n_{\text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3}= \frac{0.4126\ \text{g}}{105.99\ \text{g mol}^{-1}}
   = 3.893\times10^{-3}\ \text{mol}
   \]

3. **Moles of HClO\(_4\) that reacted with Na\(_2\)CO\(_3\)**  

   \[
   \text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3 + 2\text{HClO}_4 \rightarrow \dots
   \]
   \[
   n_{\text{HClO}_4,\;react}=2\,n_{\text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3}
   = 7.786\times10^{-3}\ \text{mol}
   \]

4. **Balance of the acid in the main experiment**  

   Total acid added: \(M_{\text{HClO}_4}(0.04000\ \text{L})\)  

   Excess acid titrated with NaOH: \(M_{\text{NaOH}}(0.00920\ \text{L})\)

   \[
   M_{\text{HClO}_4}(0.04000)-M_{\text{NaOH}}(0.00920)=7.786\times10^{-3}
   \tag{2}
   \]

5. **Insert (1) into (2) and solve for \(M_{\text{NaOH}}\)**  

   \[
   \left(\frac{M_{\text{NaOH}}\times0.02500}{0.02693}\right)(0.04000)-M_{\text{NaOH}}(0.00920)=7.786\times10^{-3}
   \]

   \[
   M_{\text{NaOH}}\bigl[\,0.03715-0.00920\,\bigr]=7.786\times10^{-3}
   \]

   \[
   M_{\text{NaOH}}(0.02795)=7.786\times10^{-3}
   \]

   \[
   M_{\text{NaOH}}=\frac{7.786\times10^{-3}}{0.02795}=2.79\times10^{-1}\ \text{M}
   \]

\[
\boxed{0.279}\ \text{M}
\]

question: A 3.00 - L sample of urban air was bubbled through a solution containing 50.0 mL of 0.0116 M $\ce{Ba(OH)_2}$, which caused the $\ce{CO_2}$ in the sample to precipitate as $\ce{BaCO_3}$. The excess base was back - titrated to a phenolphthalein end point with 23.6 mL of 0.0108 M HCl. Calculate concentration of $\ce{CO_2}$ in the air in parts per million (that is, mL $\ce{CO_2}$/$10^6$ mL air); use 1.98 g/L for the density of $\ce{CO_2}$.

Chromel is an alloy composed of nickel, iron, and chromium. A 0.6553 - g sample was dissolved and diluted to 250.0 mL. When a 50.00 - mL aliquot of 0.05173 M EDTA was mixed with an equal volume of the diluted sample, all three ions were chelated, and a 5.34 - mL back - titration with 0.06139 M copper(II) was required. The chromium in a second 50.0 - mL aliquot was masked through the addition of hexamethylenetetramine; titration of the Fe and Ni required 36.98 mL of 0.05173 M EDTA. Iron and chromium were masked with pyrophosphate in a third 50.0 - mL aliquot, and the nickel was titrated with 24.53 mL of the EDTA solution. Calculate the percentages of nickel in the alloy.

An unknown cadmium(II) solution was analyzed polarographically by the method of standard additions. A 25.00 - mL sample of the unknown solution produced a diffusion current of 1.86 ??A. Following addition of a 5.00 - mL aliquot of \(2.12\times10^{-3}\ \text{M}\ \ce{Cd^{2+}}\) standard solution to the unknown solution, a diffusion current of 5.27 ??A was produced. Calculate the concentration of \(\ce{Cd^{2+}}\) in the unknown solution.
llm_output:
The diffusion current is proportional to the concentration of cadmium in the cell.

\[
\frac{i_2}{i_1}= \frac{C_{\text{after}}}{C_{\text{before}}}
\]

Before the addition (25.00 mL)  

\[
C_{\text{before}} = C_{\text{x}}
\]

After adding 5.00 mL of a \(2.12\times10^{-3}\,\text{M}\) standard, the total volume is 30.00 mL.  
The amount of Cd\(^{2+}\) added is  

\[
n_{\text{add}} = (2.12\times10^{-3}\,\text{M})(5.00\times10^{-3}\,\text{L})
               = 1.06\times10^{-5}\,\text{mol}
\]

so its concentration in the final mixture is  

\[
C_{\text{add}} = \frac{1.06\times10^{-5}\,\text{mol}}{0.0300\,\text{L}}
               = 3.53\times10^{-4}\,\text{M}
\]

The original unknown solution is diluted from 25.00 mL to 30.00 mL, giving a factor \(25/30 = 0.8333\). Hence  

\[
C_{\text{after}} = 0.8333\,C_{\text{x}} + 3.53\times10^{-4}\,\text{M}
\]

Using the measured currents  

\[
\frac{i_2}{i_1}= \frac{5.27}{1.86}=2.834
\]

\[
2.834 = \frac{0.8333\,C_{\text{x}} + 3.53\times10^{-4}}{C_{\text{x}}}
      = 0.8333 + \frac{3.53\times10^{-4}}{C_{\text{x}}}
\]

\[
\frac{3.53\times10^{-4}}{C_{\text{x}}}=2.834-0.8333=2.001
\]

\[
C_{\text{x}} = \frac{3.53\times10^{-4}}{2.001}=1.77\times10^{-4}\,\text{M}
\]

\[
\boxed{1.77\times10^{-4}} \text{ M}
\]

question: A 0.4126 - g sample of primary - standard $\ce{Na_2CO_3}$ was treated with 40.00 mL of dilute perchloric acid. The solution was boiled to remove $\ce{CO_2}$, following which the excess $\ce{HClO_4}$ was back - titrated with 9.20 mL of dilute NaOH. In a separate experiment, it was established that 26.93 mL of the $\ce{HClO_4}$ neutralized the NaOH in a 25.00 - mL portion. Calculate the molarities of the $\ce{HClO_4}$.
llm_output:
The reaction between the primary‑standard carbonate and perchloric acid is  

\[
\ce{Na2CO3 + 2 HClO4 -> 2 NaClO4 + H2O + CO2}
\]

Moles of \(\ce{Na2CO3}\):

\[
n_{\ce{Na2CO3}}=\frac{0.4126\ \text{g}}{M_{\ce{Na2CO3}}}
               =\frac{0.4126}{105.99}\ \text{mol}=3.894\times10^{-3}\ \text{mol}
\]

Hence moles of \(\ce{HClO4}\) that react with the carbonate:

\[
n_{\text{consumed}} = 2\,n_{\ce{Na2CO3}} = 7.788\times10^{-3}\ \text{mol}
\]

Let \(M_{\ce{HClO4}}\) be the molarity of the perchloric‑acid solution and \(M_{\ce{NaOH}}\) that of the NaOH solution used for the back‑titration.

Total moles of \(\ce{HClO4}\) added (40.00 mL):

\[
n_{\text{total}} = M_{\ce{HClO4}}\,(0.04000\ \text{L})
\]

Moles of excess \(\ce{HClO4}\) (titrated by NaOH, 9.20 mL):

\[
n_{\text{excess}} = M_{\ce{NaOH}}\,(0.00920\ \text{L})
\]

Thus  

\[
M_{\ce{NaOH}}(0.00920)=M_{\ce{HClO4}}(0.04000)-7.788\times10^{-3}\qquad (1)
\]

A separate calibration gave the relation between the two solutions:

\[
M_{\ce{HClO4}}(0.02693)=M_{\ce{NaOH}}(0.02500)\qquad (2)
\]

From (2),

\[
M_{\ce{NaOH}} = M_{\ce{HClO4}}\frac{0.02693}{0.02500}=1.0772\,M_{\ce{HClO4}}
\]

Insert this into (1):

\[
1.0772\,M_{\ce{HClO4}}(0.00920)=M_{\ce{HClO4}}(0.04000)-7.788\times10^{-3}
\]

\[
0.009910\,M_{\ce{HClO4}} = 0.04000\,M_{\ce{HClO4}} - 7.788\times10^{-3}
\]

\[
0.0300898\,M_{\ce{HClO4}} = 7.788\times10^{-3}
\]

\[
M_{\ce{HClO4}} = \frac{7.788\times10^{-3}}{0.0300898}=2.59\times10^{-1}\ \text{M}
\]

\[
\boxed{0.259}\ \text{M}
\]

question: A sensitive method for $\ce{I^-}$ in the presence of $\ce{Cl^-}$ and $\ce{Br^-}$ entails oxidation of the $\ce{I^-}$ to $\ce{IO_3^-}$ with $\ce{Br_2}$. The excess $\ce{Br_2}$ is then removed by boiling or by reduction with formate ion. The $\ce{IO_3^-}$ produced is determined by addition of excess $\ce{I^-}$ and titration of the resulting $\ce{I_2}$. A 1.307 - g sample of mixed halides was dissolved and analyzed by the foregoing procedure. A volume of 19.72 mL of 0.04926 M thiosulfate was required for the titration. Calculate the percentage of $\ce{KI}$ in the sample.
llm_output:
The thiosulfate used reacts with the iodine produced:

\[
\text{I}_2 + 2\;\text{S}_2\text{O}_3^{2-}\rightarrow 2\;\text{I}^- + \text{S}_4\text{O}_6^{2-}
\]

\[
n_{\text{S}_2\text{O}_3^{2-}} = M V = 0.04926\;\text{M}\times 0.01972\;\text{L}=9.714\times10^{-4}\;\text{mol}
\]

\[
n_{\text{I}_2}= \frac{n_{\text{S}_2\text{O}_3^{2-}}}{2}=4.857\times10^{-4}\;\text{mol}
\]

The iodate formed from the original iodide reacts with excess iodide:

\[
\text{IO}_3^- + 5\;\text{I}^- + 6\;\text{H}^+ \rightarrow 3\;\text{I}_2 + 3\;\text{H}_2\text{O}
\]

Thus \(1\;\text{mol}\;\text{IO}_3^-\) gives \(3\;\text{mol}\;\text{I}_2\):

\[
n_{\text{IO}_3^-}= \frac{n_{\text{I}_2}}{3}=1.62\times10^{-4}\;\text{mol}
\]

The amount of \(\text{I}^-\) originally present (from KI) equals the amount of \(\text{IO}_3^-\):

\[
n_{\text{I}^-}=1.62\times10^{-4}\;\text{mol}
\]

Mass of KI in the sample:

\[
m_{\text{KI}} = n_{\text{I}^-}\,M_{\text{KI}} = (1.62\times10^{-4}\;\text{mol})(166.0\;\text{g mol}^{-1}) = 2.69\times10^{-2}\;\text{g}
\]

Mass percent of KI in the 1.307‑g sample:

\[
\%\,\text{KI}= \frac{2.69\times10^{-2}\;\text{g}}{1.307\;\text{g}}\times 100 = 2.06\%
\]

\[
\boxed{2.06}\% \text{ KI}
\]

question: Given that the average molar mass of the polymer chains in this sample of poly(lactic acid) (PLA) is \pu{595 g mol^{-1}} using end-group analysis, where \pu{0.1619 g} of PLA was dissolved in \pu{25 cm^3} of benzyl alcohol and titrated with \pu{0.0400 mol dm^{-3}} \ce{KOH} solution. The volume of \ce{KOH} solution required to reach the endpoint was \pu{6.81 cm^3}. What is the average number of monomer units in each polymer chain of this sample?

A 5.00 - mL sample of brandy was diluted to 1.000 L in a volumetric flask. The ethanol ($\ce{C_2H_5OH}$) in a 25.00 - mL aliquot of the diluted solution was distilled into 50.00 mL of 0.02000 M $\ce{K_2Cr_2O_7}$ and oxidized to acetic acid with heating: $$\ce{3C_2H_5OH + 2Cr_2O_7^{2-} + 16H^+ \to 4Cr^{3+} + 3CH_3COOH + 11H_2O}$$ After cooling, 20.00 mL of 0.1253 M $\ce{Fe^{2+}}$ was pipetted into the flask. The excess $\ce{Fe^{2+}}$ was then titrated with 7.46 mL of the standard $\ce{K_2Cr_2O_7}$ to a diphenylamine sulfonic acid end point. Calculate the percent (w/v) $\ce{C_2H_5OH}$ (46.07 g/mol) in the brandy.

Chromel is an alloy composed of nickel, iron, and chromium. A 0.6553 - g sample was dissolved and diluted to 250.0 mL. When a 50.00 - mL aliquot of 0.05173 M EDTA was mixed with an equal volume of the diluted sample, all three ions were chelated, and a 5.34 - mL back - titration with 0.06139 M copper(II) was required. The chromium in a second 50.0 - mL aliquot was masked through the addition of hexamethylenetetramine; titration of the Fe and Ni required 36.98 mL of 0.05173 M EDTA. Iron and chromium were masked with pyrophosphate in a third 50.0 - mL aliquot, and the nickel was titrated with 24.53 mL of the EDTA solution. Calculate the percentages of iron in the alloy.
llm_output:
The 0.6553 g alloy was diluted to 250.0 mL, so each 50.0 mL aliquot contains  

\[
\frac{50.0\ \text{mL}}{250.0\ \text{mL}}\times0.6553\ \text{g}=0.13106\ \text{g}
\]

of the alloy.

---

### 1.  Total metal (Fe + Ni + Cr) in the first aliquot  

EDTA added:  

\[
0.05000\ \text{L}\times0.05173\ \text{M}=2.5865\times10^{-3}\ \text{mol}
\]

Back‑titration with Cu(II):  

\[
0.00534\ \text{L}\times0.06139\ \text{M}=3.2782\times10^{-4}\ \text{mol}
\]

Unreacted EDTA = moles Cu(II) = \(3.2782\times10^{-4}\) mol  

\[
\text{EDTA that reacted}=2.5865\times10^{-3}-3.2782\times10^{-4}
=2.2587\times10^{-3}\ \text{mol}
\]

Thus  

\[
n_{\text{Fe}}+n_{\text{Ni}}+n_{\text{Cr}}=2.2587\times10^{-3}\ \text{mol}
\tag{1}
\]

---

### 2.  Fe + Ni (Cr masked)  

EDTA used:  

\[
0.03698\ \text{L}\times0.05173\ \text{M}=1.91298\times10^{-3}\ \text{mol}
\]

\[
n_{\text{Fe}}+n_{\text{Ni}}=1.91298\times10^{-3}\ \text{mol}
\tag{2}
\]

---

### 3.  Ni only (Fe and Cr masked)  

EDTA used:  

\[
0.02453\ \text{L}\times0.05173\ \text{M}=1.26894\times10^{-3}\ \text{mol}
\]

\[
n_{\text{Ni}}=1.26894\times10^{-3}\ \text{mol}
\tag{3}
\]

---

### 4.  Amount of Fe  

From (2) and (3):

\[
n_{\text{Fe}} = (n_{\text{Fe}}+n_{\text{Ni}})-n_{\text{Ni}}
               =1.91298\times10^{-3}-1.26894\times10^{-3}
               =6.4404\times10^{-4}\ \text{mol}
\]

Mass of Fe in one aliquot:

\[
m_{\text{Fe}} = n_{\text{Fe}}\times M_{\text{Fe}}
               =6.4404\times10^{-4}\ \text{mol}\times55.845\ \frac{\text{g}}{\text{mol}}
               =3.5965\times10^{-2}\ \text{g}
\]

The whole sample contains five such aliquots, so

\[
m_{\text{Fe,total}} =5\times3.5965\times10^{-2}=1.7983\times10^{-1}\ \text{g}
\]

---

### 5.  Percent iron in the alloy  

\[
\%\,\text{Fe}= \frac{m_{\text{Fe,total}}}{m_{\text{sample}}}\times100
             =\frac{0.17983\ \text{g}}{0.6553\ \text{g}}\times100
             =27.45\%
\]

\[
\boxed{27.45}\ \text{Fe}
\]

question: Chromel is an alloy composed of nickel, iron, and chromium. A 0.6553 - g sample was dissolved and diluted to 250.0 mL. When a 50.00 - mL aliquot of 0.05173 M EDTA was mixed with an equal volume of the diluted sample, all three ions were chelated, and a 5.34 - mL back - titration with 0.06139 M copper(II) was required. The chromium in a second 50.0 - mL aliquot was masked through the addition of hexamethylenetetramine; titration of the Fe and Ni required 36.98 mL of 0.05173 M EDTA. Iron and chromium were masked with pyrophosphate in a third 50.0 - mL aliquot, and the nickel was titrated with 24.53 mL of the EDTA solution. Calculate the percentages of chromium in the alloy.

Molar absorptivity data for the cobalt and nickel complexes with 2,3 - quinoxalinedithiol are $\varepsilon_{\ce{Co}} = 36,400$ and $\varepsilon_{\ce{Ni}} = 5520$ at 510 nm and $\varepsilon_{\ce{Co}} = 1240$ and $\varepsilon_{\ce{Ni}} = 17,500$ at 656 nm. A 0.425 - g sample was dissolved and diluted to 50.0 mL. A 25.0 - mL aliquot was treated to eliminate interferences; after addition of 2,3 - quinoxalinedithiol, the volume was adjusted to 50.0 mL. This solution had an absorbance of 0.446 at 510 nm and 0.326 at 656 nm in a 1.00 - cm cell. Calculate the concentration in parts per million of cobalt in the sample.

Poly(lactic acid) (PLA) can be broken down enzymatically to lactic acid monomer and compound B (a dimer of lactic acid). A plastic sample degraded to \pu{1.044 g}, and titration showed it needed \pu{19.40 cm^3} of \pu{0.100 mol dm^{-3}} \ce{NaOH} to neutralize. What is the number of moles of acid in the sample?

Molar absorptivity data for the cobalt and nickel complexes with 2,3 - quinoxalinedithiol are $\varepsilon_{\ce{Co}} = 36,400$ and $\varepsilon_{\ce{Ni}} = 5520$ at 510 nm and $\varepsilon_{\ce{Co}} = 1240$ and $\varepsilon_{\ce{Ni}} = 17,500$ at 656 nm. A 0.425 - g sample was dissolved and diluted to 50.0 mL. A 25.0 - mL aliquot was treated to eliminate interferences; after addition of 2,3 - quinoxalinedithiol, the volume was adjusted to 50.0 mL. This solution had an absorbance of 0.446 at 510 nm and 0.326 at 656 nm in a 1.00 - cm cell. Calculate the concentration in parts per million of nickel in the sample.
llm_output:
The absorbances of the mixture at the two wavelengths are the sum of the contributions from Co(II) and Ni(II):

\[
\begin{cases}
A_{510}= \varepsilon_{\text{Co},510}\,c_{\text{Co}}+\varepsilon_{\text{Ni},510}\,c_{\text{Ni}}\\[2pt]
A_{656}= \varepsilon_{\text{Co},656}\,c_{\text{Co}}+\varepsilon_{\text{Ni},656}\,c_{\text{Ni}}
\end{cases}
\]

with \(b=1.00\;\text{cm}\).  
Insert the data (absorbances in a 1‑cm cell):

\[
\begin{cases}
0.446 = 36400\,c_{\text{Co}} + 5520\,c_{\text{Ni}}\\[2pt]
0.326 = 1240\,c_{\text{Co}} + 17500\,c_{\text{Ni}}
\end{cases}
\]

Solve the simultaneous equations (Cramer’s rule):

\[
\begin{aligned}
\Delta &= 36400(17500)-5520(1240)=6.301552\times10^{8}\\[4pt]
